title: Guide: VS Code Remote (WSL on Windows) to CERN lxplus
content: Guide: VS Code Remote (WSL on Windows) to CERN lxplus Skip to main content Home / Technical Help / VS Code Remote via WSL Using VS Code Remote via WSL on Windows to Connect to CERN lxplus (and Other Linux Servers) 1. Installing and Setting up WSL and SSH on Windows On Windows 10/11 you can enable the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) by running the wsl --install command in an elevated PowerShell:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}. This will install the default Linux distro (usually Ubuntu) and set it up. Once WSL is installed and restarted, open the Linux shell (Ubuntu). You should have an SSH client available (Ubuntu typically includes openssh-client by default). If it's not present, install it with sudo apt update && sudo apt install openssh-client . (Windows itself also offers an OpenSSH client feature, but using WSL's SSH ensures you use the same Linux-style configuration and key files as your other Linux tools:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.) Optional tip: It's recommended to use WSL 2 (which has a full Linux kernel) for better compatibility. You can check your WSL version with wsl -l -v and upgrade if needed:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}. 2. Installing and Configuring VS Code and Remote-SSH Install Visual Studio Code on Windows if you haven't already:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}. During installation, choose the "Add to PATH" option so you can launch it from the terminal with code . :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}. Once VS Code is installed, open it and install the Remote - SSH extension from the Extensions Marketplace:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}. (If you plan to open VS Code from within WSL, you may also install the "Remote - WSL" extension:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}, but the key steps below assume you use the Remote-SSH extension.) After installing Remote-SSH, configure it to use your SSH client. By default it will use your system's ssh . You can leave this as is (it will use WSL's ssh when VS Code is launched from WSL). If VS Code does not pick up WSL's ssh , you can create a wrapper script (e.g. ssh.bat ) that calls wsl.exe ssh %* and set the VS Code setting remote.SSH.path to that batch file:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}. This ensures VS Code uses the same SSH configuration and keys as your WSL environment. OpenSSH client: Ensure a compatible OpenSSH client is installed:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}. On Windows this is usually present by default or can be enabled in Optional Features. In WSL (Ubuntu), the ssh command is typically already available. VS Code: Install VS Code (with "Add to PATH"):contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}. Extensions: In VS Code's Extensions, install "Remote - SSH":contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10} (and optionally "Remote - WSL" if using WSL natively). Initial setup: After installation, press F1 (or Ctrl+Shift+P) and select "Remote-SSH: Connect to Host..." to start configuring a new SSH host:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}. 3. Setting up SSH Keys in WSL It's strongly recommended to use SSH key-based authentication for remote hosts:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}. In your WSL shell, generate a new SSH key pair if you don't have one: for example, ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -f ~/.ssh/id_rsa , and follow the prompts (you can leave the passphrase empty for passwordless login, or set one for more security). This creates ~/.ssh/id_rsa (private key) and ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub (public key). Next, copy your public key to lxplus: one way is ssh-copy-id username@lxplus.cern.ch , which logs into lxplus and installs your key. If ssh-copy-id is not available, you can manually append the contents of ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on lxplus (after logging in once with your password). This allows you to authenticate without a password. Tip: Make sure your private key file is secure: chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_rsa and chmod 700 ~/.ssh . SSH will refuse to use keys that are accessible by others:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}. You can also add your key to the ssh-agent in WSL ( eval "$(ssh-agent -s)" && ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa ) so you don't have to enter a passphrase repeatedly. Once keys are in place, test in WSL: ssh username@lxplus.cern.ch should log you in without a password. This confirms the key setup. 4. Configuring SSH Access to lxplus Edit your WSL SSH config file ~/.ssh/config (create it if it doesn't exist) and add an entry for lxplus. For example: Host lxplus HostName lxplus.cern.ch User yourusername IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa Replace yourusername with your CERN account name. With this config, you can simply run ssh lxplus instead of the full host name. VS Code will also use this entry when you connect. Proxying and additional hosts: If you need to connect to other machines inside CERN's network via lxplus, you can add more entries. For example, to reach somehost.cern.ch behind lxplus: Host somehost HostName somehost.cern.ch User yourusername ProxyJump lxplus This uses lxplus as a jump host. Now ssh somehost will tunnel through lxplus. This is similar to the example in CERN's documentation:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}. Load balancing tip: lxplus is a cluster front-end, so SSH goes to random nodes. To avoid VS Code's server launching on different nodes, enable SSH multiplexing: under the Host lxplus entry add: ControlMaster auto ControlPath ~/.ssh/sockets/%r@%h-%p ControlPersist 60 This reuses the first connection for all subsequent sessions:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}, ensuring stability. (Create the directory ~/.ssh/sockets first.) 5. Connecting to lxplus Using VS Code With SSH set up, start VS Code (you can launch it from WSL by running code . in a WSL terminal to ensure it uses the Linux environment:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}). In VS Code, open the Command Palette (F1) and choose Remote-SSH: Connect to Host... , then type lxplus (or yourusername@lxplus.cern.ch ) as the host:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}. VS Code will use the SSH client to connect. If prompted, accept lxplus's host key and enter your passphrase if you set one. Once connected, VS Code will install its server components on lxplus. You will then have a new (empty) VS Code window connected to lxplus:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}. You can open any remote folder or workspace via File ‚Üí Open. The VS Code terminal will now run on lxplus, and you can work on files there seamlessly. Extensions on Remote: When first connected, VS Code may ask you to install any needed extensions on lxplus. Ensure your language support extensions (Python, C++, etc.) are enabled in the remote context. 6. Generalizing to Other Remote Servers Connecting to other Linux servers works the same way. For each server, generate or reuse an SSH key, install the public key on the server (e.g. using ssh-copy-id ), and add a corresponding entry in ~/.ssh/config : Host myserver HostName myserver.example.com User remoteuser IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_myserver Then use "Remote-SSH: Connect to Host" in VS Code and select myserver . VS Code will SSH into it and open the remote folder. You can also connect to Windows servers (if they run an SSH server) similarly. The process of key-based auth, config entries, and VS Code Remote is the same:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}. If the server uses a nonstandard port, add a Port line in the config or include -p in the connection command. You can chain multiple hops with multiple Host entries and ProxyJump if needed:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}. 7. Troubleshooting Common Problems SSH permissions: If you see errors about file permissions on your private key or ~/.ssh directory, fix them (e.g. chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_rsa , chmod 700 ~/.ssh ):contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}. SSH requires strict permissions on keys and configs. Connection hangs or fails: Check the VS Code "Remote - SSH" output log (View ‚Üí Output, select "Remote - SSH") for clues. You can also try manually SSHing from WSL (e.g. ssh -v lxplus ) to debug issues. Make sure the host names and user names in your config match exactly. Wrong user or host: In VS Code, ensure you connect using User@Host that matches your ~/.ssh/config (or use the host alias). If VS Code uses the wrong SSH config, set the remote.SSH.configFile to point to WSL's ~/.ssh/config (e.g. \\\\wsl$\\Ubuntu\\home\\username\\.ssh\\config ) so it uses the same file. VS Code server errors: If the VS Code Remote server fails to start, try killing it on the remote host: connect via normal SSH and run rm -rf ~/.vscode-server , then reconnect. This forces a clean reinstall. Also ensure your home directory on lxplus has enough space and is not on a slow network file system. Using WSL's ssh in VS Code: If VS Code cannot find ssh or you want it to use WSL's environment, set remote.SSH.path as described above:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}. This ensures VS Code runs the ssh command inside WSL, so it uses your Linux keys and config. Load balancing on lxplus: If VS Code seems to connect then suddenly disconnect (or you have to enter password again), it could be switching nodes. Using ControlMaster (see above) usually fixes this:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}. Also make sure the HostName is lxplus.cern.ch , not a specific node name, unless you know exactly which node. Firewall and network: If you are offsite (outside CERN network), you may need to set up an SSH tunnel or VPN to access lxplus. CERN documentation suggests using SSH tunneling or VPN for off-campus access. Check CERN IT guidelines if you can't reach lxplus from home. Sources Microsoft WSL Installation Guide ‚Äì Official instructions for installing WSL on Windows:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}. VS Code Remote - SSH (Microsoft Docs) ‚Äì Official documentation on installing and using the Remote-SSH extension:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}. VS Code Remote - WSL (Microsoft Docs) ‚Äì Instructions for using WSL with VS Code:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}. CERN ATLAS Software Docs: VS Code Remote Usage with SSH ‚Äì Guide to using VS Code with SSH at CERN (includes tips on tunneling and ProxyJump):contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}. CERN BILPA Guide: Remote-SSH ‚Äì Example configuration for connecting VS Code to remote hosts via lxplus (with ProxyJump ):contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}. title: Modelo 720: Foreign Asset Declaration - CERN Starter Pack
content: Modelo 720: Foreign Asset Declaration - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Legal & Tax Help / Modelo 720 Modelo 720: Foreign Asset Declaration Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Disclaimer This page is for general informational purposes only. It does not constitute legal, financial, or tax advice. Always consult a qualified advisor for your specific situation. What is Modelo 720? Modelo 720 is an informative declaration (not a tax payment) that Spanish tax residents must file to report assets held outside Spain. It was introduced by Law 7/2012 and developed by Real Decreto 1558/2012. The declaration applies when the total value of assets in any of the three defined categories exceeds 50,000 euros. It is purely informational: filing Modelo 720 does not result in any tax payment by itself, but failure to file can trigger significant penalties. Who Must File? Any individual who is a tax resident of Spain and who holds assets abroad exceeding the thresholds must file Modelo 720. This includes CERN employees who maintain their fiscal residence in Spain. CERN-specific considerations apply: if you live and work in Geneva or Pays de Gex but remain a Spanish tax resident (for example, because your family stays in Spain or your centre of vital interests is there), you are subject to this obligation. Non-residents of Spain do NOT need to file Modelo 720. If you have transferred your tax residence abroad, this declaration does not apply to you. The Three Categories Modelo 720 groups foreign assets into three independent categories, each with its own 50,000 euro threshold: Category 1 - Bank accounts: Current accounts, savings accounts, term deposits, and any other bank accounts held at financial institutions located outside Spain. Category 2 - Securities, insurance, and annuities: Shares, investment funds, life insurance policies, and pension rights held abroad. For CERN employees, the CERN Pension Fund falls under this category. Category 3 - Real estate: Any property (land, buildings, apartments) located outside Spain, including property in France or Switzerland. Each category is evaluated independently. You only need to declare the categories where your total holdings exceed 50,000 euros. For example, if you have 60,000 euros in Swiss bank accounts but only 30,000 euros in French property, you would only declare Category 1. Filing Deadlines & Re-filing Rules The initial Modelo 720 declaration must be filed between 1 January and 31 March of the year following the one in which you first exceeded the 50,000 euro threshold in any category. In subsequent years, you only need to re-file for a given category if the total value of assets in that category has increased by more than 20,000 euros compared to the last declaration you submitted for that category. CERN-Specific Considerations CERN employees who are Spanish tax residents typically have several types of foreign assets that may need to be declared: Swiss bank accounts: If you hold accounts at Swiss or French banks (e.g. UBS, Credit Suisse, BNP Paribas) with combined balances exceeding 50,000 euros, these must be declared under Category 1. CERN Pension Fund: Your accumulated rights in the CERN Pension Fund are generally considered to fall under Category 2 (securities, insurance, and annuities). When the accumulated value exceeds 50,000 euros, you should declare it. French or Swiss property: If you own an apartment or house in France or Switzerland, it must be declared under Category 3 when its acquisition value exceeds 50,000 euros. Post-2022 ECJ Ruling In January 2022, the Court of Justice of the European Union (Case C-788/19) ruled that the penalty regime associated with Modelo 720 was disproportionate and contrary to EU law. The court found that the fines and the presumption of unjustified capital gains were excessive. Following the ruling, Spain reformed the penalty system through Law 5/2022. The disproportionate fines were removed, and the regime was aligned with standard tax infraction penalties. However, the obligation to declare foreign assets through Modelo 720 remains fully in force. Modelo 721: Crypto Assets Since 2024, Spanish tax residents must also file Modelo 721 to declare cryptocurrency holdings on foreign exchanges. This new form follows the same logic as Modelo 720, with an independent 50,000 euro threshold for crypto assets held on platforms located outside Spain. Step-by-Step Filing Walkthrough Access the Agencia Tributaria electronic office at sede.agenciatributaria.gob.es . Authenticate using your digital certificate (certificado digital), DNIe, or Cl@ve PIN. Navigate to the Modelo 720 form and fill in the relevant categories with details of your foreign assets, including account numbers, ISIN codes, property references, and balances as of 31 December. Review the declaration carefully and submit it electronically. Save or print the confirmation receipt for your records. title: Returning to Spain - CERN Starter Pack
content: Returning to Spain - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Legal & Tax Help / Returning to Spain Returning to Spain: Step-by-Step Guide Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Disclaimer This page is for general informational purposes only. It does not constitute legal, financial, or tax advice. The content is not official and should not be used as a substitute for professional guidance. Please consult a qualified advisor for your specific situation. Before Leaving Geneva (3-6 months before) Notify CERN HR: Inform your supervisor and HR department of your departure date. Confirm end-of-contract formalities, final salary payment, and any leaving indemnity or pension options. Request certificates: Obtain your CERN employment certificate, internal tax certificates for all years worked, and a pension fund statement showing your accumulated rights and options. Baja consular: Visit the Spanish Consulate to process your consular de-registration (baja consular). This formally records your return to Spain and is needed for certain administrative steps back home. Convenio especial: If you have been paying the convenio especial with Spanish Social Security, decide whether to continue it until your return date or terminate it once you are back and re-employed in Spain. Medical records: Collect your complete medical records, prescriptions, and any ongoing treatment documentation from CERN CHIS. Request a coverage end-date certificate from CHIS. Pension fund options: Review your CERN Pension Fund options: deferred pension, lump-sum withdrawal, or transfer. Deadlines for certain elections may apply, so consult the Pension Fund office early. Notify your commune: De-register from your Swiss commune (or French mairie). Return your carte de legitimation and cancel any local insurance, utilities, and subscriptions. Administrative Steps on Arrival in Spain Empadronamiento: Register at your local town hall (ayuntamiento) as soon as you have a residential address in Spain. The padron certificate is essential for healthcare, voting, and other services. Certificado de emigrante retornado: Apply at the Delegacion or Subdelegacion del Gobierno for a returning emigrant certificate. This document can unlock certain benefits and is proof of your time spent abroad. DNI update: Update your DNI with your new Spanish address at a police station (comisaria). If your DNI has expired while abroad, renew it as a priority since it is required for most administrative procedures. Healthcare & Social Security Re-entering the healthcare system: Once empadronado, visit your local Social Security office (INSS or CAISS) to register for public healthcare. If you maintained the convenio especial, you should have continuity of coverage. Otherwise, you may need to register as a resident without resources or wait until you start employment. Convenio especial coverage: If you maintained the convenio especial, your healthcare and pension rights remain active. Present your convenio documentation and padron certificate at the INSS to confirm your status. SEPE path: If you return without employment, register at SEPE (public employment service) as a jobseeker. This is a prerequisite for accessing certain benefits and active employment programmes, even if you do not qualify for unemployment benefits. Employment & Unemployment (SEPE) Register at SEPE: As a returning emigrant, register as a jobseeker (demandante de empleo) at your local SEPE office. Bring your returning emigrant certificate, padron, DNI, and CERN employment certificate. CERN years do NOT count for paro: Time at CERN does not generate Spanish unemployment benefit rights, since no unemployment contributions were paid to Spain. You cannot claim prestacion por desempleo based on CERN employment alone. EU coordination: EU social security coordination regulations do not apply to CERN employment because CERN is outside national social security systems. If you previously had Spanish unemployment contributions within the last six years, check whether those older contributions are still within the look-back window to qualify for benefits. CERN Pension: Options & Spanish Taxation Deferred pension: If you are vested in the CERN Pension Fund (typically after five years of service), you can leave your benefits in the fund and draw a pension when you reach CERN retirement age. The pension will be paid monthly by CERN. Lump sum: You may be eligible to withdraw a lump-sum leaving allowance instead of a deferred pension, depending on your length of service and the fund rules at the time. Consult the Pension Fund office for details and tax implications. Transfer: In certain cases, you may be able to transfer your CERN pension rights to another pension scheme. This option is limited and subject to specific agreements between CERN and the receiving institution. IRPF taxation: Unlike CERN salaries (which are exempt), CERN pensions received by Spanish tax residents are subject to IRPF. Spain considers the CERN pension as rendimientos del trabajo and taxes it under the standard income tax brackets. Plan accordingly, as the net amount will be lower than the gross pension. Financial & Practical Matters Closing bank accounts: Close or restructure your Swiss and French bank accounts as needed. Some people keep a foreign account for pension payments or ongoing obligations. Notify your banks of your change of tax residence. Transferring savings: Use low-cost transfer services (Wise, Revolut) to move savings from CHF or EUR accounts to your Spanish bank. Be aware of large-transfer reporting requirements in Spain (Modelo S-1 for transfers above 10,000 euros). Importing your car: If you bring a vehicle registered abroad into Spain, you must register it with the DGT (Direccion General de Trafico) within 30 days. You may be exempt from import duties if you qualify as a returning resident (under the household goods exemption), but you must apply at customs (Aduana) with proof of your foreign residence. Household goods: Returning emigrants can import personal belongings duty-free if they have lived abroad for at least 12 months. Prepare an inventory and present it at customs along with your returning emigrant certificate and proof of prior residence abroad. Tax Implications of the Return Year Full tax resident: Spain determines tax residence for the full calendar year. If you return before July, you will likely be considered tax resident for the entire year and must declare your worldwide income for that year. Exempt months: CERN salary received during the months you were still a CERN employee remains exempt under the Protocol on Privileges and Immunities. Only non-CERN income and any Spanish employment income after your return are taxable. Modelo 720: If you still hold foreign assets above the 50,000 euro threshold on 31 December of the return year, you must file Modelo 720 in the following year (January-March). This includes Swiss or French bank accounts, CERN pension fund rights, and foreign property. First IRPF declaration: In your first Spanish tax return after returning, declare your worldwide income for the year, applying the CERN salary exemption for the months worked at CERN. Attach the CERN internal tax certificate and any other documentation supporting the exemption. content: Housing & Daily Life Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Housing & Daily Life Housing & Daily Life Near CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Note Prices and details on this page are approximate and may change. Always verify with official sources before making decisions. Switzerland vs France: Overview Factor Switzerland (Geneva) France (Pays de Gex) Rent Very high (CHF 1,800-3,000+/month for 2-3 rooms) Moderate (EUR 800-1,500/month for similar size) Healthcare CHIS primary; LAMal optional for CERN staff CHIS primary; CMU/PUMA optional for residents Commute 5-20 min by bus/bike from Meyrin area 10-30 min by car; bus options available Language French (Geneva is French-speaking) French Income tax CERN salary exempt from Swiss income tax CERN salary exempt; must file French return Cost of living Very high (groceries, dining, services) Significantly lower than Switzerland Popular Areas In Switzerland Meyrin: Closest to CERN's main entrance. Short commute, local shops and markets, suburban feel. Popular with CERN employees for convenience. Vernier: Affordable by Geneva standards. Good bus connections to CERN. More residential, with a multicultural community. Geneva centre: Vibrant city life, excellent amenities and nightlife. Higher rents and longer commute to CERN (20-30 min by bus). Carouge: Charming neighbourhood south of Geneva centre. Artistic atmosphere, good restaurants. Slightly longer commute but well connected by tram. In France Saint-Genis-Pouilly: Directly adjacent to CERN. Many CERN employees live here. Good local amenities, supermarkets, and schools. Short drive or bus ride to CERN. Ferney-Voltaire: Charming town with good schools and restaurants. Close to the Swiss border and Geneva airport. Popular with international families. Gex: Small historic town at the foot of the Jura mountains. Quieter and more rural, with a weekly market. Slightly longer commute. Thoiry: Residential area with good value housing. Close to skiing and outdoor activities in the Jura. Growing community of CERN families. Annemasse: Larger town on the French-Swiss border south of Geneva. Lower rents, connected to Geneva by Leman Express train. Longer commute to CERN. Finding Housing CERN Housing Service: CERN offers a Housing Service that maintains a list of available rentals and can assist newcomers. Check the CERN internal website or contact the Users Office for details. Temporary on-site accommodation (CERN hostel) may be available for your first weeks. Websites: In Switzerland: homegate.ch, immoscout24.ch, comparis.ch. In France: seloger.com, leboncoin.fr, bien-ici.com. Cross-border: CERN Market (internal) and local Facebook groups. Facebook groups: Search for groups like "CERN Housing", "Expats in Geneva", "Pays de Gex Expats". These often have listings and useful advice from other CERN employees. Scam warnings: Be wary of listings that seem too good to be true, request money upfront before viewing, or use suspicious payment methods. Always visit the property in person before signing any contract. Transport TPG: Transports Publics Genevois operates buses and trams in the Geneva area. Lines 66 and 68 serve CERN directly. A monthly pass (Unireso) covers all public transport in the Geneva zone. Unireso: The integrated fare system covering TPG buses/trams, SBB trains, and Mouettes boats in the Greater Geneva area. Monthly passes available for different zones. Leman Express: Regional train connecting Geneva to surrounding French towns (Annemasse, Annecy corridor). Useful if you live south of the border. CERN shuttles: CERN operates internal shuttle buses between its sites (Meyrin and Prevessin campuses). Free for CERN personnel. Cycling: The area is generally flat and cycle-friendly. CERN has bike racks at most buildings. Geneva has a bike-sharing scheme (Donkey Republic/Velospot). Car: Many people living in France commute by car. Parking is available at CERN but can be limited. Cross-border commuters typically need a G permit for Switzerland. Health Insurance CHIS: The CERN Health Insurance Scheme is your primary coverage. It covers medical expenses in Switzerland, France, and abroad. All CERN employees and their registered dependents are enrolled automatically. LAMal: Swiss mandatory health insurance. CERN staff with a carte de legitimation are exempt and do not need LAMal. However, family members without CERN status working in Switzerland may need to enrol. CMU/PUMA: French universal healthcare. CERN employees living in France are generally exempt from compulsory affiliation thanks to CHIS coverage. If your partner works in France outside CERN, they would join the French system. Banking Swiss accounts: Traditional banks (UBS, BCGE) often require Swiss residency and charge significant fees. Useful for receiving salary in CHF and paying Swiss rent. CERN may help with introductions to local banks. French accounts: Banks like BNP Paribas, Societe Generale, or online banks (Boursorama, Fortuneo) are options for those living in France. Needed for French rent payments and direct debits. Multi-currency options: Digital banks like Wise, Revolut, and N26 are popular with CERN employees for low-fee currency exchange between CHF and EUR and international transfers. Groceries & Shopping Swiss supermarkets: Migros and Coop are the main chains. Lidl and Aldi offer lower prices. Shopping in Switzerland is significantly more expensive than in France. French supermarkets: Carrefour, Leclerc, Lidl, and Intermarche in the Pays de Gex area offer much lower prices than Swiss equivalents. Many Swiss residents cross the border to shop in France. CERN cafeterias: CERN has several restaurants and cafeterias on site (Restaurant 1, Restaurant 2, etc.) offering affordable meals. Coffee corners and vending machines are available throughout the campus. title: Kerberos & SSH Setup for CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Kerberos & SSH Setup for CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Technical Help / Kerberos & SSH Setup Kerberos & SSH Setup for CERN Last updated: February 2026 This guide covers Kerberos and SSH configuration for Linux , macOS , and Windows via WSL . Choose the section that matches your operating system. What is Kerberos and Why CERN Uses It Kerberos is a network authentication protocol that uses tickets to prove identity without sending passwords over the network. CERN operates the CERN.CH Kerberos realm for centralized authentication across its computing infrastructure. When you authenticate with Kerberos, you receive a time-limited ticket-granting ticket (TGT) that lets you access CERN services such as lxplus, AFS, EOS, and GitLab without re-entering your password each time. This ticket-based system is fundamental to working at CERN. Linux Setup Install the Kerberos client tools on Debian/Ubuntu-based distributions: sudo apt update && sudo apt install krb5-user Then configure /etc/krb5.conf with the CERN realm settings. Replace the contents of the file (or create it) with: [libdefaults] default_realm = CERN.CH ticket_lifetime = 25h renew_lifetime = 120h forwardable = true proxiable = true [realms] CERN.CH = { kdc = cerndc.cern.ch master_kdc = cerndc.cern.ch default_domain = cern.ch kpasswd_server = afskrb5m.cern.ch admin_server = afskrb5m.cern.ch } [domain_realm] .cern.ch = CERN.CH cern.ch = CERN.CH On Fedora/RHEL, install with sudo dnf install krb5-workstation . The krb5.conf file is the same. macOS Setup macOS ships with a built-in Kerberos implementation (Heimdal). You do not need to install additional packages. Simply create or edit the file /etc/krb5.conf with the same configuration shown in the Linux section above. On modern macOS you may need to use sudo to edit files in /etc/ . Also note that macOS Heimdal may handle ticket renewal slightly differently; if you experience issues, try setting renewable = true in the [libdefaults] section. Windows / WSL Setup On Windows, the recommended approach is to use WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux). Inside your WSL distribution (e.g., Ubuntu), install and configure Kerberos exactly as described in the Linux section above. If you also want to use VS Code Remote to connect to lxplus, see the VS Code Remote via WSL guide for complementary setup instructions on SSH through WSL. Getting a Kerberos Ticket Once your configuration is in place, use these commands to manage Kerberos tickets: # Obtain a new ticket (you will be prompted for your CERN password) kinit username@CERN.CH # List current tickets and expiration times klist # Renew an existing ticket (before it expires) kinit -R # Destroy all tickets (log out) kdestroy Replace username with your CERN account name. Tickets are valid for 25 hours by default and renewable for up to 5 days, as specified in the configuration above. SSH Configuration for lxplus To connect to lxplus using your Kerberos ticket (no password needed), add the following to your ~/.ssh/config file: Host lxplus HostName lxplus.cern.ch User yourusername GSSAPIAuthentication yes GSSAPIDelegateCredentials yes GSSAPITrustDns yes ForwardAgent yes With this configuration and a valid Kerberos ticket, you can simply run ssh lxplus and you will be authenticated automatically via GSSAPI (Kerberos). Replace yourusername with your CERN login. SSH Tunneling & Off-site Access When working from outside the CERN network, you may need to use lxtunnel.cern.ch as a jump host. Add this to your ~/.ssh/config : Host lxtunnel HostName lxtunnel.cern.ch User yourusername GSSAPIAuthentication yes GSSAPIDelegateCredentials yes Host lxplus-tunnel HostName lxplus.cern.ch User yourusername ProxyJump lxtunnel GSSAPIAuthentication yes GSSAPIDelegateCredentials yes You can also set up a SOCKS proxy through lxplus for accessing CERN-internal web services from off-site: ssh -D 1080 -N lxplus Then configure your browser to use localhost:1080 as a SOCKS5 proxy to reach internal CERN pages. Keytab for Automated Access For scripts or automated processes that need Kerberos authentication without interactive login, you can create a keytab file: cern-get-keytab --keytab ~/private/keytab --login --user yourusername Then obtain a ticket non-interactively with: kinit -kt ~/private/keytab yourusername@CERN.CH Security warning: A keytab file is equivalent to a stored password. Protect it with strict file permissions ( chmod 600 ) and never share it or commit it to version control. Accessing EOS and AFS With a valid Kerberos ticket, you can access CERN storage systems: EOS (CERN's distributed storage) can be accessed on lxplus with the eos command-line tool: # List your EOS home directory eos ls /eos/user/u/username/ # Copy a file to EOS eos cp localfile.txt /eos/user/u/username/ # Mount EOS via FUSE (if available) mkdir -p ~/eos eosfusebind ~/eos AFS (Andrew File System) requires an AFS token, which you obtain from your Kerberos ticket: # Get an AFS token from your Kerberos ticket aklog # Access your AFS workspace ls /afs/cern.ch/user/u/username/ Troubleshooting kinit: Cannot find KDC for realm CERN.CH — Your /etc/krb5.conf is missing or misconfigured. Verify the file exists and contains the correct realm settings. kinit: Client not found in Kerberos database — Check that you are using the correct CERN username and the realm is CERN.CH (uppercase). Permission denied (GSSAPI) — Run klist to check if your ticket is valid and not expired. Run kinit again if needed. Ticket expired or cannot renew — If your ticket has been expired for too long, renewal will fail. Run kdestroy followed by kinit to get a fresh ticket. SSH connection refused off-site — CERN restricts direct SSH access from outside its network. Use the lxtunnel ProxyJump configuration described above. Clock skew too great — Kerberos requires synchronized clocks. Ensure your system clock is correct (use NTP). A skew of more than 5 minutes will cause authentication failures. Quick Reference Card Task Command Get a Kerberos ticket kinit user@CERN.CH List current tickets klist Renew ticket kinit -R Destroy tickets kdestroy SSH to lxplus ssh lxplus SSH via tunnel (off-site) ssh lxplus-tunnel SOCKS proxy ssh -D 1080 -N lxplus Get AFS token aklog List EOS files eos ls /eos/user/u/user/ Create keytab cern-get-keytab --keytab ~/private/keytab --login --user user References CERN Kerberos Setup Documentation CERN lxplus Service CERN EOS Storage Service CERN AFS Service CERN SSH Key Recommendations Print this page

title: ROOT Framework Quick-Start - CERN Starter Pack
content: ROOT Framework Quick-Start - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Technical Help / ROOT Quick-Start ROOT Framework Quick-Start Guide Last updated: February 2026 What is ROOT? ROOT is an open-source C++ and Python framework developed at CERN for data processing, statistical analysis, visualization, and storage in high-energy physics (HEP). It is the standard tool for analyzing particle physics data and is used by virtually every experiment at CERN. ROOT provides specialized data structures (such as TTree for columnar data), histogramming, curve fitting, and a powerful I/O system based on the .root file format. It also includes CLING, an interactive C++ interpreter, and PyROOT, a Python interface to all ROOT classes. Zero-Install Option: SWAN If you want to start using ROOT immediately without installing anything, CERN provides SWAN (Service for Web-based ANalysis) at swan.cern.ch . SWAN is a JupyterHub-based service that gives you a notebook environment with ROOT, PyROOT, and many other scientific Python packages pre-installed. Simply log in with your CERN credentials, choose a software stack, and start coding. SWAN connects to your EOS storage, so you can access your data files directly. This is the fastest way to get started with ROOT at CERN. Installation Methods Conda (Recommended for personal machines) The easiest way to install ROOT on your personal machine is via conda-forge: conda create -n root-env conda activate root-env conda install -c conda-forge root Snap (Linux) On Linux distributions that support Snap packages: sudo snap install root-framework Homebrew (macOS) On macOS with Homebrew installed: brew install root Pre-built Binaries Download pre-compiled binaries for your platform from the official ROOT website at root.cern/install . Extract the archive and source the setup script: tar -xzf root_v6.XX.YY.Linux-ubuntu22-x86_64-gcc11.4.tar.gz source root/bin/thisroot.sh On lxplus (CVMFS) On CERN's lxplus machines, ROOT is available through CVMFS without any installation. Simply set up the LCG software environment: # List available LCG releases ls /cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/ # Set up a specific LCG release (example) source /cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/LCG_105/x86_64-el9-gcc13-opt/setup.sh # Verify ROOT is available root --version First Steps with ROOT Interactive C++ (CLING) Launch ROOT's interactive C++ interpreter by typing root in your terminal: $ root root [0] TH1F *h = new TH1F("h", "My Histogram", 100, -5, 5); root [1] h->FillRandom("gaus", 10000); root [2] h->Draw(); root [3] .q PyROOT Use ROOT from Python with the PyROOT bindings: import ROOT # Create and fill a histogram h = ROOT.TH1F("h", "Gaussian Distribution;x;Entries", 100, -5, 5) h.FillRandom("gaus", 10000) # Draw on a canvas c = ROOT.TCanvas("c", "My Canvas", 800, 600) h.Draw() c.SaveAs("histogram.png") Reading .root Files Open and explore an existing ROOT file: import ROOT f = ROOT.TFile.Open("data.root") f.ls() # List contents tree = f.Get("Events") # Get a TTree tree.Print() # Show branches tree.Draw("pt") # Quick plot of a branch NumPy / pandas Integration Convert ROOT data to NumPy arrays or pandas DataFrames for use with the broader Python ecosystem: import ROOT import numpy as np # Using RDataFrame (modern ROOT approach) df = ROOT.RDataFrame("Events", "data.root") npy = df.AsNumpy(["pt", "eta"]) # Returns dict of NumPy arrays # Convert to pandas DataFrame import pandas as pd pdf = pd.DataFrame(npy) Essential Resources ROOT Reference Documentation ROOT Tutorials (with source code) RDataFrame Documentation SWAN - Service for Web-based ANalysis ROOT User Forum ROOT on GitHub Common First-Week Tasks Open a SWAN session and run a ROOT tutorial notebook to get familiar with the environment. Set up ROOT on lxplus using CVMFS and run root --version to confirm it works. Ask your supervisor or team for a sample .root file from your experiment and practice opening it with TFile and browsing its contents. Try creating a histogram from a TTree branch using both the C++ interpreter and PyROOT. Explore RDataFrame, ROOT's modern analysis interface, for filtering, defining new columns, and creating plots. Install ROOT on your personal laptop (via Conda or Homebrew) so you can develop offline. Bookmark the ROOT forum and reference documentation for when you need help. Print this page

title: CERN GitLab & Development Workflow - CERN Starter Pack
content: CERN GitLab & Development Workflow - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Technical Help / CERN GitLab CERN GitLab & Development Workflow Last updated: February 2026 CERN GitLab vs GitHub CERN hosts its own GitLab instance at gitlab.cern.ch . This is the primary platform for version control and collaboration on CERN software projects. Unlike public GitHub, CERN GitLab is integrated with CERN Single Sign-On (SSO) and is accessible to anyone with a CERN computing account. While many open-source HEP projects also maintain mirrors on GitHub, the authoritative repositories for experiment frameworks, internal tools, and configuration management typically live on CERN GitLab. Your group or experiment will likely require you to use it for day-to-day development. Authentication Methods CERN GitLab supports several authentication methods: CERN SSO (web): Log in to the GitLab web interface using your CERN credentials. This is automatic if you are already logged into CERN SSO. SSH keys: The preferred method for command-line Git operations. Set up once and use without entering passwords. Kerberos: Clone and push using your Kerberos ticket via the https://:@gitlab.cern.ch:8443/ URL scheme. Personal Access Token (PAT): Generate a token in GitLab settings for HTTPS-based authentication. Useful for scripts and CI/CD integrations. Setting Up SSH Keys for GitLab Generate an SSH key pair if you do not already have one: ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.name@cern.ch" Copy the public key to your clipboard: cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub Then add it to your CERN GitLab account: Go to gitlab.cern.ch/-/user_settings/ssh_keys Paste your public key into the "Key" field Give it a descriptive title (e.g., "Laptop - Ubuntu 2026") Click "Add key" Test the connection: ssh -T git@gitlab.cern.ch Add this to your ~/.ssh/config for convenience: Host gitlab.cern.ch User git IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519 PreferredAuthentications publickey Kerberos Authentication for Git If you prefer to use Kerberos instead of SSH keys, you can clone repositories using the Kerberos-authenticated HTTPS endpoint on port 8443: # First, get a Kerberos ticket kinit username@CERN.CH # Clone using the Kerberos URL git clone https://:@gitlab.cern.ch:8443/group/project.git This method is especially convenient on lxplus where you already have a Kerberos ticket. No additional configuration is needed beyond a valid ticket. Basic Git Workflow at CERN Most CERN projects follow a merge-request-based workflow similar to the standard GitLab flow: Fork or branch: Create a personal fork of the project or a feature branch (depending on your project's conventions). Develop locally: Clone the repo, create a branch, make your changes, and commit. Push: Push your branch to your fork or the upstream repository. Open a Merge Request (MR): On the GitLab web interface, create a merge request targeting the main branch. Add a description, assign reviewers. Code review: Respond to feedback, push additional commits if needed. Merge: Once approved, the MR is merged (usually by the maintainer or yourself if you have permissions). # Typical workflow commands git clone git@gitlab.cern.ch:group/project.git cd project git checkout -b my-feature # ... make changes ... git add -A && git commit -m "Add new feature" git push origin my-feature # Then open MR on GitLab web UI CI/CD on CERN GitLab CERN GitLab provides built-in CI/CD pipelines powered by GitLab Runners. Many shared runners are available, including runners that can access CVMFS for experiment software. To set up CI/CD for your project, create a .gitlab-ci.yml file in the repository root: stages: - build - test build-job: stage: build image: gitlab-registry.cern.ch/linuxsupport/alma9-base script: - source /cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/LCG_105/x86_64-el9-gcc13-opt/setup.sh - mkdir build && cd build - cmake .. && make test-job: stage: test image: gitlab-registry.cern.ch/linuxsupport/alma9-base script: - source /cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/LCG_105/x86_64-el9-gcc13-opt/setup.sh - cd build && ctest CERN provides shared runners with tags like cvmfs for accessing experiment software stacks. Check your project's CI settings or ask your team about the preferred runner configuration. Useful Repositories for Newcomers Here are some commonly referenced repositories and groups on CERN GitLab: Experiment frameworks: Each major experiment (ATLAS, CMS, LHCb, ALICE) has its own GitLab group containing the analysis and reconstruction frameworks. Ask your supervisor for the specific repositories you need. CERN IT tools: The cern-it and linuxsupport groups contain infrastructure tools, container images, and system configurations. ROOT project: The ROOT framework itself is developed on GitHub ( github.com/root-project/root ) but many ROOT-based tools and packages live on CERN GitLab. Documentation projects: Many groups maintain their documentation as GitLab Pages sites (using mkdocs, sphinx, or similar). Explore your experiment's docs group for guides and tutorials. title: Health Insurance at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Health Insurance at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Health Insurance Health Insurance at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important Making the wrong choice or missing a deadline on health insurance can be costly and irreversible. Read this page carefully and act within the required timeframes. CHIS: Your Primary Coverage The CERN Health Insurance Scheme (CHIS) is your primary health coverage. All CERN employees are enrolled automatically upon joining. CHIS covers medical expenses, hospitalisation, dental (partial), maternity, and emergency care in Switzerland, France, and abroad. Your registered family members (spouse, children) can also be covered under CHIS. Register them through the CERN HR department as soon as possible. CHIS is not a state insurance ‚Äî it is CERN's own scheme, managed independently from Swiss or French national systems. If You Live in Switzerland Exemption from LAMal: CERN staff holding a carte de legitimation are exempt from the Swiss mandatory health insurance (LAMal). You do not need to enrol in a Swiss health insurance plan. Family members: If your spouse or family members do not hold CERN status and work in Switzerland, they may need their own LAMal coverage. Check with the cantonal office (Office cantonal de l'assurance maladie, Geneva). No action needed: If you and your family are fully covered by CHIS and nobody works outside CERN in Switzerland, no additional insurance is required. Optional LAMal: You may voluntarily opt into LAMal for additional coverage. Compare premiums at priminfo.admin.ch before deciding. If You Live in France (Cross-border ‚Äî Critical) ⚠️ If you live in France, you must make a health insurance choice within 3 months of registering your residence. This choice is normally irreversible. The Droit d'Option As a cross-border worker (frontalier) living in France and working at CERN, you have the right to choose between three health coverage options: Option A ‚Äî CHIS only: Keep your CERN insurance as your sole coverage. No affiliation with the French system. Simplest option for most CERN employees. Option B ‚Äî French system (CMU/PUMA): Affiliate with the French social security system via CPAM (Caisse Primaire d'Assurance Maladie). You would pay contributions to URSSAF based on your income. This provides access to the full French healthcare network. Option C ‚Äî Swiss LAMal: Enrol in Swiss mandatory health insurance at the frontalier rate. Provides coverage in both Switzerland and France but involves Swiss premium payments. Deadline and Process 3-month deadline: You have 3 months from the date you register your residence in France (at the mairie) to exercise your droit d'option. If you miss this deadline, you may be automatically assigned to the French system. Irreversible choice: Once you exercise the droit d'option, your choice is normally permanent for as long as you remain in the same situation (same employer, same country of residence). S1 form: If you choose CHIS only (Option A), you may need an S1 form to prove you have health coverage. CERN's HR department can help you obtain the necessary documentation. Where to declare: Submit your choice to CPAM de l'Ain (if you live in the Pays de Gex area) or the relevant CPAM for your department. CHIS Reimbursement: How It Works Claims portal: Submit reimbursement claims through the CHIS online portal or by sending paper forms to the CHIS office at CERN. Receipts: Keep all medical receipts, prescriptions, and invoices. You will need to attach them to your claim. Reimbursement rates: CHIS reimburses a percentage of eligible costs (typically 80-90% for most services). Check the CHIS schedule of benefits for exact rates. Emergency abroad: CHIS provides emergency coverage worldwide. Keep your CHIS card with you when travelling and contact the CHIS office for pre-authorisation if possible. Useful Contacts & Links CHIS ‚Äî CERN Health Insurance Scheme Ameli.fr ‚Äî French Health Insurance (CPAM) Priminfo ‚Äî Swiss Premium Comparison CERN Admin e-Guide 🖨 Print this guide

title: FAQ - CERN Starter Pack
content: FAQ - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / FAQ Frequently Asked Questions General Where do I collect my CERN access card? Your CERN access card is collected at the CERN Reception (Building 33). Bring your passport or national ID and your contract documentation. The Users Office will guide you through the process during your first day. See the CERN Admin e-Guide for details. Why doesn't my computing account work? Your CERN computing account may take 24-48 hours to become fully active after creation. If it still doesn't work, try resetting your password at account.cern.ch . For persistent issues, contact the CERN Service Desk. Do I need a Swiss bank account? CERN can pay your salary to a bank account in most countries. A local Swiss or French account is useful for paying rent and local bills. Many CERN employees also use multi-currency digital banks like Wise or Revolut. What is EDH and how do I use it? EDH (Electronic Document Handling) is CERN's system for administrative processes: travel requests, leave applications, expense claims, and more. Access it through the CERN intranet. Your supervisor can help you get started with your first requests. Health Insurance I live in France ‚Äî what do I do about health insurance? You have 3 months from registering your French residence to exercise your "droit d'option" ‚Äî choosing between CHIS only, the French system (CMU/PUMA), or Swiss LAMal. Most CERN employees choose CHIS only. See our Health Insurance guide for full details. Can I change my health insurance choice later? Generally no. The droit d'option choice is normally irreversible as long as your situation stays the same (same employer, same country of residence). A change of circumstances (e.g., moving from France to Switzerland) may allow a new choice. How do I submit a CHIS reimbursement claim? Submit claims through the CHIS online portal or send paper forms to the CHIS office at CERN. Always keep original receipts and prescriptions. Reimbursement typically covers 80-90% of eligible costs. Housing & Transport Should I live in Switzerland or France? Both have advantages. Switzerland (Geneva) is closer to CERN and has excellent public transport but is very expensive. France (Pays de Gex) is much more affordable but may require a car. See our Housing guide for a detailed comparison. How do I get a transport pass? For Geneva public transport (TPG), purchase a Unireso monthly pass at TPG offices or online at tpg.ch. CERN may offer subsidised transport passes ‚Äî check with HR. Lines 66 and 68 serve CERN directly. Is a car necessary? Not if you live in Geneva or close to a bus line serving CERN. If you live in some parts of the Pays de Gex (France), a car is very helpful as public transport options are more limited. CERN also runs internal shuttle buses between its sites. Legal & Admin Do I need to register at a commune/mairie? Yes. If you live in Switzerland, register at your commune's Office de la population. If you live in France, register at the mairie of your town. CERN staff in Switzerland receive a carte de legitimation instead of a standard residence permit. What is the carte de legitimation? The carte de legitimation is a special identity document issued by the Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs to international organisation employees. It replaces a standard residence permit and grants certain privileges, including exemption from Swiss income tax and LAMal. Do I need to file taxes in France? If you live in France, you must file an annual French tax return even though your CERN salary is exempt from French income tax. You declare your situation and the exemption applies. Other income (rental, investments) may be taxable in France. Tech How do I connect to eduroam Wi-Fi? Use your CERN credentials (username@cern.ch and your CERN password) to connect to the eduroam network. For the best setup, use the eduroam CAT tool at cat.eduroam.org. The CERN-GUEST network is available as a fallback. How do I access lxplus from home? Connect via SSH: ssh username@lxplus.cern.ch . You will need Kerberos authentication or an SSH key configured in your CERN account. See our Kerberos & SSH guide for setup instructions. What is ServiceNow? ServiceNow is CERN's central platform for IT support tickets, HR requests, facility issues, and general service requests. Access it at cern.service-now.com using your CERN credentials. It replaces the old ticketing system. 🖨 Print this page

title: Banking Setup Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Banking Setup Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Banking Setup Banking Setup Near CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Note Banking products, fees, and requirements may change. Always verify with the bank directly before opening an account. Why You Need Bank Accounts CERN pays salaries in Swiss francs (CHF), so a Swiss bank account is essential for receiving your salary. If you live in France, you will need a French bank account for rent payments, utilities, and direct debits in euros (EUR). Living near the Swiss-French border means you deal with two currencies daily. Having accounts in both currencies simplifies payments and avoids costly exchange fees. Swiss Bank Accounts Main banks: UBS and BCGE (Banque Cantonale de Geneve) are the most commonly used by CERN employees. Credit Suisse has been integrated into UBS. Required documents: Carte de legitimation (issued by CERN/DFAE), valid passport or ID, employment contract or CERN attestation, and proof of address (if available). Typical fees: CHF 5-15 per month for account maintenance, depending on the bank and account type. Some banks offer reduced fees for CERN staff. Opening process: Book an appointment at the branch (in-person required for most Swiss banks). Bring all documents. The account is usually active within a few business days. A debit card (Maestro or Visa Debit) is issued by post. French Bank Accounts Traditional banks: BNP Paribas, Societe Generale, and Credit Agricole have branches in Saint-Genis-Pouilly and Ferney-Voltaire near CERN. Online banks: Boursorama and Fortuneo offer fee-free current accounts and are popular with CERN employees living in France. Fully digital application process. Required documents: Titre de sejour or attestation from the prefecture, valid passport or ID, proof of address in France (utility bill or rental contract), and employment contract. Opening process: Traditional banks require an in-person appointment. Online banks can be opened remotely in a few days. A French RIB (Releve d'Identite Bancaire) is needed for rent and utility payments. On-Site Banking at CERN UBS branch: There is a UBS branch located at CERN (Building 504) specifically serving CERN personnel. Staff there are experienced with the carte de legitimation and CERN employment contracts. ATMs: UBS and BCGE ATMs are available on the CERN Meyrin site for cash withdrawals in CHF. Opening hours: The on-site UBS branch typically operates on limited hours (mornings only on certain weekdays). Check the CERN website or internal directory for current hours. Appointments: It is recommended to book an appointment in advance, especially during arrival periods (September-October) when many newcomers open accounts simultaneously. Multi-Currency & Digital Banks Wise (formerly TransferWise): Very popular among CERN employees. Offers multi-currency accounts with real exchange rates and low fees. Ideal for CHF/EUR conversions and international transfers. Revolut: Provides multi-currency accounts, free card payments abroad, and competitive exchange rates. Useful for daily cross-border spending. N26: German digital bank offering free euro accounts. Available to French residents. Good as a secondary EUR account. Limitations: Digital banks may not always be accepted for salary deposits by CERN. They also may lack French RIB functionality needed for some direct debits. Best used as complementary accounts rather than primary ones. Salary Payment Currency: CERN pays all salaries in Swiss francs (CHF). You will need to provide a CHF-denominated IBAN to the HR department. Split payments: CERN allows you to split your salary between multiple bank accounts (e.g., part in CHF to a Swiss account, part converted to EUR to a French account). Contact HR/payroll to set this up. First payment: Your first salary payment may take 4-6 weeks after your start date. Plan to have enough savings to cover your initial expenses (deposit, rent, living costs) during this period. Tips Open Swiss first: Prioritise opening a Swiss bank account as soon as possible after arrival so you can receive your salary without delay. French account if needed: If you live in France, open a French account for rent, utilities, and local payments. Many landlords require a French RIB for direct debit. Use Wise/Revolut daily: For everyday cross-border spending (groceries in France, coffee in Switzerland), digital banks offer the best exchange rates and lowest fees. Avoid airport exchanges: Currency exchange offices at Geneva airport and in tourist areas charge high commissions. Use your bank card or digital bank instead. title: Transportation Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Transportation Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Transportation Transportation Near CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Note Schedules, fares, and routes may change. Always check official transport websites for the latest information. Getting to CERN Meyrin site: The main CERN campus is located in Meyrin, Switzerland, accessible via Entrance B on Route de Meyrin. This is where most offices, restaurants, and the main reception are located. Prevessin site: The second CERN campus is in Prevessin-Moens, France. It hosts several experimental areas and offices. A free CERN shuttle connects the two sites. Main options: You can reach CERN by public bus, CERN shuttle, bicycle, car, or regional train (to nearby stations). The best option depends on where you live. Public Transport (TPG) Bus line 68: The most important bus for CERN employees. It runs from Geneva city centre (Rive) through Meyrin to the CERN stop. Frequency is every 10-15 minutes during peak hours. Tram 18: Tram line 18 runs from Plan-les-Ouates through Geneva to CERN (the terminus). It is the fastest public transport link between Geneva centre and CERN, taking about 25 minutes from Cornavin station. Unireso zones and passes: The Geneva area uses the Unireso fare system. A monthly pass costs approximately CHF 70 and covers all TPG buses, trams, and local trains within the selected zones. Buying tickets: Tickets can be purchased via the TPG app (recommended), at ticket machines at major stops, or on board (with a surcharge). Contactless payment is accepted on some machines. CERN Shuttle Free service: CERN operates a free internal shuttle bus between the Meyrin and Prevessin sites. Available to all CERN personnel and visitors with a valid access card. Schedule: The shuttle runs every 15-20 minutes during standard working hours (approximately 08:00 to 18:00, Monday to Friday). Check the CERN transport page for the current timetable. Route: The shuttle connects key buildings on both sites, with stops at the main entrances and major building clusters. Cycling Flat terrain: The area around CERN is generally flat, making cycling a practical and popular commuting option, especially from Meyrin and Saint-Genis-Pouilly. Bike racks: CERN provides bike racks at most buildings across both sites. Covered racks are available near main entrances. Bike-sharing: Geneva offers bike-sharing services such as Donkey Republic. Stations are available near CERN and throughout the city. Bike paths: Dedicated bike paths connect Meyrin and Saint-Genis-Pouilly to CERN. The route from Geneva centre follows well-marked paths along Route de Meyrin. Electric bikes: Electric bike rental services are available in Geneva and nearby towns. Some CERN employees use e-bikes for the slightly longer commute from Ferney-Voltaire or Gex. Driving & Parking Parking: Parking is available at both CERN sites but can be limited, especially at Meyrin during peak hours. A CERN access card is required for the parking barriers. Cross-border commuting: Many employees living in France commute by car. The border crossing near CERN (Entrance E) is usually quick but can have delays during rush hour. French motorway vignette: Not needed for local roads in the Pays de Gex area. Only required if using French motorways further afield. Swiss vignette: A Swiss motorway vignette costs CHF 40 per year and is required for using Swiss motorways. Available at border crossings, post offices, and petrol stations. Regional Trains Leman Express: The regional train network connecting Geneva to Annemasse and the Annecy corridor. Useful if you live south of the border or in towns along the line. SBB/CFF: Swiss Federal Railways operates frequent trains between Geneva (Cornavin) and Lausanne, as well as connections to the rest of Switzerland. The Geneva station is about 20 minutes from CERN by bus. For longer commutes: If you live further from CERN (e.g., Nyon, Lausanne, Annemasse), combining train and bus can be an efficient commute option. From Geneva Airport By bus/tram: Take bus 23, 28, or 57 from the airport to Blandonnet, then transfer to tram 18 or bus 68 towards CERN. The total journey takes about 25-35 minutes depending on connections. By taxi: A taxi from Geneva airport to CERN costs approximately CHF 40-50 and takes about 10-15 minutes by car depending on traffic. Proximity: CERN is very close to Geneva airport (approximately 5 km). This makes it convenient for international travel and for visitors arriving by air. title: Cross-Border Shopping Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Cross-Border Shopping Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Cross-Border Shopping Cross-Border Shopping Near CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Note Prices, customs limits, and opening hours may change. Always check with official sources for the latest regulations. Why Cross-Border Shopping? Price differences: There are significant price differences between Switzerland and France. Groceries and everyday items can be 20-40% cheaper in France compared to Swiss supermarkets. Common practice: Many CERN employees, whether living in Switzerland or France, regularly shop across the border to save money on groceries, wine, and household products. Proximity: French supermarkets in Saint-Genis-Pouilly and Ferney-Voltaire are just minutes from CERN, making cross-border shopping easy and practical. French Supermarkets Carrefour: Located in Saint-Genis-Pouilly. Large hypermarket with a wide selection of food, household goods, and electronics. Competitive prices. Leclerc: Branches in Thoiry and Ferney-Voltaire. Known for competitive pricing. The Thoiry location has a large shopping centre with additional stores. Lidl: Budget supermarket with locations near Saint-Genis and Ferney. Great for staples and weekly special offers on non-food items. Intermarche: Available in several nearby towns. Good selection of French products, local cheeses, and wines at reasonable prices. Opening hours: Typically 8:30 to 19:30 (Monday to Saturday). Some supermarkets open on Sunday mornings until 12:30. Hours may vary by location and season. Swiss Supermarkets Migros: Switzerland's largest supermarket chain. Good quality own-brand products. Higher prices than France but convenient for quick stops. Does not sell alcohol. Coop: Second-largest Swiss chain. Wider product range including alcohol. Slightly higher prices than Migros for most items. Lidl and Aldi: Swiss branches of these discount chains offer lower prices than Migros/Coop, though still generally higher than French equivalents. Comparison: For a typical weekly shop, you may save CHF 50-100 by shopping in France instead of Switzerland, depending on what you buy. Customs & Tax-Free Value limit: When importing goods from France to Switzerland for personal use, there is a CHF 300 value limit per person per day. Below this amount, no customs duties apply. Green/red channels: At the border crossing, use the green channel if you have nothing to declare (under the limit). Use the red channel if you exceed the limit or carry restricted items. VAT refund (detaxe): Swiss residents can claim a VAT refund on purchases made in France above a certain threshold. Ask for a detaxe form at the shop checkout and have it stamped at the French border customs. Common limits: Specific limits apply to certain goods: 1 kg of meat, 1 kg of butter, 5 litres of wine, and 1 litre of spirits per person per day when entering Switzerland. Amounts above these limits are subject to duties. Sunday & Holiday Hours Switzerland: Most shops are closed on Sundays, except those at train stations (Geneva Cornavin) and some convenience stores in the city centre. Shops in Geneva may open on the first Sunday of the month. France: Some supermarkets open on Sunday mornings until around 12:30. Bakeries and small food shops often open Sunday mornings as well. Public holidays: Switzerland and France have different public holidays. A shop may be open on one side of the border while closed on the other. Check local calendars to plan ahead. Farmers Markets Ferney-Voltaire: Saturday morning market in the town centre. Fresh local produce, cheese, bread, flowers, and regional specialities. One of the best markets in the area. Gex: Thursday morning market. Smaller but with excellent local products from the Jura region, including Comte cheese and cured meats. Geneva (Plainpalais): Large open-air market on Tuesdays, Fridays, and Sundays. Wide variety of fresh produce, artisan goods, and international food stalls. Fresh produce: Markets offer seasonal, locally sourced fruits, vegetables, dairy, and meats at competitive prices. A great way to discover regional French and Swiss products. Tips Keep receipts: Always keep your shopping receipts when crossing the border. Customs officers may ask to see them, and you will need them for any VAT refund claims. Use Wise/Revolut for EUR: If your salary is in CHF, use a multi-currency card (Wise, Revolut) for paying in euros at French shops to get the best exchange rate. Stock up on French goods: Wine, cheese, bread, and fresh produce are significantly cheaper and often better quality in France. Many CERN employees do a large weekly shop in France. Pharmacies: Prescription and over-the-counter medicines are generally cheaper in French pharmacies than in Swiss ones. The pharmacy in Saint-Genis-Pouilly is a popular option. Sources Swiss Customs (BAZG) French Customs (Douane) Ferney-Voltaire - Local Market Info 🖨 Print this guide

title: Childcare & Schools Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Childcare & Schools Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Childcare & Schools Childcare & Schools Near CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important Waiting lists for childcare and popular schools can be very long. Start researching and registering as early as possible, ideally before your arrival at CERN. CERN Childcare: Le Jardin des Particules Le Jardin des Particules is the CERN on-site creche, accepting children from 4 months to 6 years of age. It is managed by the CERN Staff Association and located on the Meyrin site. Places are reserved for children of CERN employees and associated personnel. There is typically a significant waitlist. Apply as soon as you receive your CERN contract, or even earlier if possible, through CERN HR. Fees are income-dependent and generally competitive compared to local private nurseries in the Geneva area. Local Nurseries (Creches) Swiss creches: Available in Meyrin, Vernier, and surrounding communes. Managed by the commune or private operators. Registration is usually done through the commune's early childhood office (Service de la petite enfance). French creches: Available in Saint-Genis-Pouilly, Ferney-Voltaire, and nearby towns. Managed by the commune or associations. Contact the local Relais Petite Enfance for availability. Registration timelines: Apply early ‚Äî waiting lists of 6 months or more are common on both sides of the border. Some communes require registration before the child is born. Cost comparison: Swiss creches tend to be more expensive (CHF 100-150/day) but fees are often income-adjusted. French creches are generally cheaper (EUR 5-30/day depending on income and CAF subsidies). Primary & Secondary Schools Swiss public schools: Free and French-language. Children are assigned to the school in their commune of residence. The school year starts in late August. Registration is done through the commune. French public schools: Free and French-language. Registration is at the local mairie. The school year starts in September. Children are assigned based on their catchment area (carte scolaire). School year differences: Swiss schools (Canton of Geneva) start in late August, while French schools start in September. School holidays also differ between the two countries. Integration classes: Both Swiss and French public schools offer integration support (classes d'accueil in Geneva, UPE2A in France) for children who do not yet speak French. International Schools International School of Geneva (Ecolint): The oldest international school in the world, with multiple campuses (La Grande Boissiere, Nations, La Chataigneraie). Offers IB curriculum in English and French. Tuition ranges from CHF 20,000 to CHF 35,000 per year. Campus des Nations: A campus of Ecolint located near the UN in Geneva, convenient for families living on the Swiss side. Lycee International de Ferney-Voltaire: A French public school with international sections (English, German, etc.). Free tuition with a small fee for the international section. Very popular with CERN families on the French side. Geneva English School: A private English-language primary school in Geneva following the English National Curriculum. CERN education grants: CERN provides education grants for staff members' children attending school. This can partially offset international school tuition. Check with CERN HR for eligibility and amounts. Higher Education & After-School Activities Nearby universities: The University of Geneva (UniGE) and EPFL/University of Lausanne are within easy reach for older students or accompanying partners. After-school programs: Swiss communes offer garderies (after-school care) and parascolaire activities. In France, centres aeres and garderies periscolaires provide similar services. Sports clubs: Numerous sports clubs for children are available through local communes, the CERN Staff Association, and private organizations in the area. Tips for Families Register early: For creches and popular international schools, apply as soon as possible ‚Äî ideally 6-12 months in advance. CERN education grants: If your children attend a fee-paying school, check with CERN HR about education grant eligibility. The grant can cover a significant portion of tuition. Check catchment areas: If you plan to use public schools, verify the catchment area (secteur scolaire) before choosing your housing. Bilingual advantage: The Geneva region offers a unique bilingual environment. Children attending local schools will naturally develop French skills alongside their home language. title: Utilities Setup Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Utilities Setup Near CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Utilities Setup Utilities Setup Near CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important Utility systems differ significantly between Switzerland and France. Start setting up accounts before your move-in date to avoid delays. Overview Switzerland and France have different utility providers, billing systems, and regulations. Your setup process depends entirely on which side of the border you live. In Switzerland, many utilities are bundled with the rental contract or handled automatically by the landlord. In France, tenants typically need to open their own accounts. Plan to set up utilities 1-2 weeks before your move-in date. Internet installation may take longer, especially in France. Electricity & Gas Switzerland (Geneva): SIG (Services Industriels de Geneve) is the sole provider for electricity, gas, and water in the Canton of Geneva. Your account is typically activated automatically when you sign your rental contract. You may need to contact SIG to confirm the transfer. France: EDF is the main electricity provider and Engie (formerly GDF Suez) for gas. You need to open an account by calling or registering online. Setup takes approximately 2 weeks. Have your new address and move-in date ready. French monthly costs: Expect approximately EUR 80-150 per month for electricity and gas combined, depending on apartment size and heating type. Meter readings: Take note of your electricity and gas meter readings on the day you move in. This protects you from being charged for the previous tenant's consumption. Water Switzerland: Water is provided by SIG and is usually included in the rental charges (charges communes). You typically do not need a separate water subscription. France: Water supply varies by commune. In some areas it is included in the communal charges; in others, you may need a separate subscription with the local water provider (e.g., Suez, Veolia, or the communal water service). Tap water quality: Tap water is safe to drink on both sides of the border. Geneva and the Pays de Gex area have excellent water quality. Internet & Mobile Switzerland: Main providers are Swisscom, Sunrise, and Salt. Fibre optic is widely available in the Geneva area. Expect to pay CHF 50-80 per month for broadband internet. France: Main providers are Orange, Free (very popular, EUR 20-40/month), SFR, and Bouygues Telecom. Free's Freebox is particularly popular for its competitive pricing and includes a TV service. Cross-border options: If you live in France and work at CERN, consider a French mobile plan with EU roaming (covers Switzerland for calls). Some providers offer specific cross-border packages. CERN Wi-Fi: CERN provides eduroam Wi-Fi on all sites. Your CERN credentials give you access. You can also use eduroam at universities and research institutions worldwide. eSIM: Most modern phones support eSIM. This can be convenient for having both a Swiss and French number without carrying two physical SIM cards. TV License Switzerland: The Serafe fee is CHF 335 per year and is mandatory for all households, regardless of whether you own a TV or radio. It is billed separately and cannot be avoided. France: The contribution a l'audiovisuel public has been phased out as of 2022. You no longer need to pay a TV license fee in France. Waste & Recycling Switzerland: Geneva uses taxed garbage bags (sacs taxe) costing approximately CHF 2 per 35-litre bag. You must use official bags purchased from supermarkets. Recycling is strongly encouraged and free ‚Äî separate paper, glass, PET, aluminium, and organic waste. Dechetterie: Each Swiss commune has a recycling centre (dechetterie) where you can drop off bulky items, electronics, and hazardous waste for free. France: Waste collection is included in local taxes (taxe d'habitation/taxe fonciere). Sorting rules are less strict than in Switzerland, but recycling is increasingly required. Yellow bins are for recyclables, green for glass. Tips Open accounts early: Contact utility providers 1-2 weeks before moving in to ensure everything is active on your arrival date. Keep all contracts: Store copies of all utility contracts and correspondence. You will need them for administrative procedures and when moving out. Bundled packages: In France, consider bundling internet, mobile, and TV with the same provider (e.g., Free) for savings. In Switzerland, Swisscom and Sunrise offer similar bundles. Meter readings at move-in: Always note electricity, gas, and water meter readings when you move in and when you move out. Take photos as evidence.
