content: On-Site Services at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / On-Site Services On-Site Services at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important CERN on-site service hours and availability may change. Always check the CERN internal directory or ServiceNow for the latest information. Restaurants & Cafeterias Restaurant 1 (R1): Located on the Meyrin site, this is the main CERN restaurant. It offers a daily menu with starter, main course, and dessert options. Open for lunch on weekdays. Restaurant 2 (R2): Located on the Prevessin site. Offers similar menu options to R1. Convenient if you work on the French side of CERN. Restaurant 3 (R3): A smaller restaurant on the Meyrin site, often offering alternative or lighter meal options. Cafeterias and coffee corners: Several cafeterias and coffee points are spread across both sites, offering sandwiches, snacks, coffee, and drinks throughout the day. Prices: Meal prices range from approximately EUR 8 to EUR 15, depending on the menu choice. Payment is made by CERN badge (charged to your account) or cash. CERN Medical Service Location: Building 57 on the Meyrin site. The medical service provides general consultations, occupational health assessments, vaccinations, and first aid. Opening hours: Monday to Friday, 8:00-12:00 and 13:30-17:00. Closed on weekends and CERN holidays. Appointments: Book appointments through the CERN medical service phone line or via the CERN ServiceNow portal. Walk-ins are possible for urgent matters. Services: General medicine, occupational health screenings, travel vaccinations, first aid, and medical certificates. The service is not a substitute for a personal doctor (medecin traitant). Banking on Site UBS branch: A UBS bank branch is located in Building 504 on the Meyrin site. It offers basic banking services including account inquiries, transfers, and currency exchange. ATMs: ATMs are available at the UBS branch and at several other locations across the Meyrin site. Opening hours: The UBS branch has limited hours. Check the CERN internal directory for current opening times, as they may differ from standard bank hours. Post Office Swiss Post counter: A Swiss Post counter is available at CERN for sending and receiving letters and packages. It offers standard postal services including registered mail and international shipping. PO boxes: CERN personnel can request a PO box at the CERN post office for receiving personal mail at work. Hours: The post office has limited opening hours. Check the CERN internal directory for current times. CERN Shop Location: The CERN Shop is located near the main reception on the Meyrin site. It sells branded CERN merchandise including T-shirts, mugs, books, and souvenirs. Opening hours: The shop is open during standard visit hours. Hours may vary during holidays and CERN shutdown periods. Library CERN Scientific Library: Located on the Meyrin site, the library provides access to scientific journals, books, conference proceedings, and CERN publications. Study spaces: The library offers quiet study areas, meeting rooms, and computer workstations available to all CERN personnel. Interlibrary loans: If a publication is not available locally, the library can request it through interlibrary loan agreements with partner institutions. Sports Facilities Gym: CERN has a fitness centre available to all personnel. Access requires a Staff Association sports membership. Football pitch: A football pitch is available on the Meyrin site for organised games and casual use. Running paths: Well-maintained running paths are available around both the Meyrin and Prevessin sites, popular with lunchtime joggers. Staff Association sports clubs: The CERN Staff Association organises numerous sports clubs including football, tennis, badminton, yoga, climbing, sailing, and many more. Check the Staff Association website for the full list and registration. Emergency Numbers CERN Fire Brigade (on site): 74444 (internal) ‚Äî for fire, accidents, and all emergencies on CERN premises. CERN Emergency (from outside): +41 22 767 4444 ‚Äî to reach the CERN Fire Brigade from an external phone. Swiss emergency numbers: 144 (ambulance), 117 (police), 118 (fire brigade). French emergency numbers: 15 (SAMU/medical), 17 (police), 18 (fire brigade), 112 (European emergency number, works in both countries). title: Vehicles & Green Plates at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Vehicles & Green Plates at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Vehicles & Green Plates Vehicles & Green Plates at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important Green plates are a privilege tied to your CERN status. Misuse or failure to return them when leaving can result in fines and customs issues. Follow all procedures carefully. Green Plates Overview CERN international staff with a carte de legitimation are eligible for CD (Corps Diplomatique) green plates, which allow tax-free vehicle registration in Switzerland. Green plates are issued by the Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs (DFAE) through CERN's Host States Relations service. The duration of your green plates is linked to your CERN contract. When your contract ends, you must return or convert your plates. Vehicles with green plates are exempt from Swiss customs duty and TVA (VAT) on purchase. This can represent significant savings. Only international staff members (not fellows or associates without a carte de legitimation) are typically eligible for green plates. Bringing Your Car Temporary importation: You can bring your existing car into Switzerland temporarily (up to 1 year) without paying customs duties, provided you have owned the vehicle for at least 6 months before arriving. Definitive importation: If you want to keep your car permanently, you must go through the customs clearance process. Present your purchase invoice, original registration, and proof of insurance at Geneva customs. Required documents: Original vehicle registration certificate, purchase invoice or proof of ownership, valid insurance certificate (green card), passport, and CERN carte de legitimation. Timing: Start the importation process as soon as possible after arriving. Delays can complicate the customs procedure. Contact CERN's Host States Relations service for guidance. Buying a Car in Switzerland Tax-free purchase: With green plates, you can buy a new car in Switzerland without paying TVA (currently 7.7%). This can save thousands of francs on a new vehicle. Process: Choose your vehicle at a Swiss dealership, inform them you will register with green plates. The dealership will prepare the invoice without TVA. CERN's Host States Relations service handles the registration paperwork. Registration steps: Submit the purchase invoice and insurance certificate to CERN's Host States Relations. They will process the green plate registration with the Swiss authorities. You will receive your plates and vehicle registration document. Dealerships: Most major Swiss dealerships are familiar with the green plate process for international organisations. Some near CERN (Geneva area) have dedicated staff for this. Buying a Car in France No tax exemption: Unlike Switzerland, buying a car in France does not benefit from any tax exemption linked to your CERN status. You will pay full French TVA (20%). Second-hand market: France has a large second-hand car market. Websites like leboncoin.fr and La Centrale are popular for finding used vehicles. Carte grise: To register a car in France, you need a carte grise (vehicle registration certificate). Apply online at the ANTS (Agence Nationale des Titres Securises) website or through an approved garage. Controle technique: Cars over 4 years old must pass a controle technique (MOT equivalent) every 2 years. Ensure any used car you buy has a valid controle technique certificate. Driving License International driving permit: An international driving permit (IDP) together with your national license is valid in Switzerland for up to 12 months from your arrival date. Exchanging to Swiss license: After 12 months, you must exchange your license for a Swiss one. Switzerland has agreements with many countries allowing a direct exchange without a driving test. CERN assistance: CERN's Host States Relations service can help you with the license exchange process, including providing the necessary attestations. No driving test: If your country has a bilateral agreement with Switzerland (most EU/EFTA countries, USA, Canada, Japan, Australia, and others), you can exchange your license without taking a Swiss driving test. France residents: If you live in France and hold a non-EU license, you may also need to exchange it for a French license. EU licenses are valid throughout France without exchange. Insurance Mandatory: Third-party liability insurance (responsabilite civile) is mandatory in both Switzerland and France. You cannot register a vehicle without proof of insurance. CERN group rates: CERN has negotiated group insurance rates with several providers. Check with the Staff Association or Host States Relations for current offers ‚Äî they can be significantly cheaper than individual quotes. Swiss vs French insurance: If your car has green plates (Swiss registration), you need Swiss insurance. If registered in France with a carte grise, you need French insurance. TCS membership: Consider joining the Touring Club Suisse (TCS) for roadside assistance, legal protection, and travel insurance. CERN staff often get discounted membership rates. Parking at CERN Parking sticker: Apply for a CERN parking sticker through ADaMS (CERN's administrative database). You will need your vehicle registration details. Meyrin site: Parking at the Meyrin site is limited and spaces fill up early in the morning. Consider arriving before 8:30 or using alternative transport. Prevessin site: The Prevessin site generally has more parking availability than Meyrin. Free shuttle buses connect the two sites. Electric charging: CERN has installed electric vehicle charging stations at both Meyrin and Prevessin sites. Check the CERN maps for locations and availability. Selling Your Car / Leaving CERN Returning green plates: When your CERN contract ends, you must return your green plates to CERN's Host States Relations service. This is mandatory and failure to do so can result in penalties. Re-export: If you are leaving Switzerland, you can re-export your vehicle to your home country or another destination without paying Swiss import duties. Selling in Switzerland: If you want to sell your green-plated car in Switzerland, the buyer must pay the customs duty and TVA that were originally exempted. Factor this into the sale price. Timeline: Start the process at least 2-3 months before your departure date. Notify Host States Relations, arrange insurance cancellation, and complete the plate return procedure. Sources CERN Admin e-Guide ‚Äî Administrative Circulars BAZG ‚Äî Swiss Federal Office for Customs and Border Security SAN ‚Äî Geneva Vehicle Registration (Service des automobiles et de la navigation) 🖨 Print this guide

title: Language Training at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Language Training at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Language Training Language Training at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important CERN language courses are very popular and fill up quickly. Register as soon as enrollment opens to secure your spot, especially for French beginner levels. Working Language at CERN CERN's two official languages are English and French. All official documents and communications are available in both languages. In practice, most day-to-day technical work, meetings, and emails are conducted in English. You can work comfortably at CERN without speaking French. However, French is extremely useful for daily life outside CERN ‚Äî shopping, dealing with local administration, visiting doctors, and socialising with neighbours. There is no strict requirement to speak French to work at CERN, but learning at least basic French will significantly improve your quality of life in the Geneva region. CERN Language Courses Languages offered: CERN offers subsidised courses in French, English, German, Spanish, Italian, and occasionally other languages depending on demand. Subsidised by CERN: Courses are heavily subsidised for CERN personnel. You only pay a small fraction of the actual cost, making them an excellent value. Schedule: Classes are offered during and after working hours. Lunchtime and evening slots are the most popular. Each course typically runs for one semester. Levels: Courses follow the CEFR framework (A1 to C2). A placement test determines your starting level. Most newcomers start at A1 or A2 for French. Enrollment: Register through the CERN Learning Hub (learning.cern.ch). Enrollment periods are announced via email and on the CERN intranet. Act fast ‚Äî courses fill up within hours. Welcome Club Language Classes Affordable group classes: The CERN Welcome Club offers affordable French classes aimed primarily at partners and family members of CERN personnel. Focus on beginners: Classes focus mainly on French for beginners and intermediate learners, with an emphasis on practical everyday communication. Social aspect: Beyond language learning, Welcome Club classes are a great way to meet other newcomers and build a social network in the CERN community. Registration: Check the Welcome Club website for current offerings, schedules, and registration details. Classes typically start at the beginning of each semester. CAGI Resources CAGI: The Centre d'Accueil de la Geneve Internationale helps international workers and their families settle in Geneva, including language support. Conversation exchange: CAGI organises conversation exchange programs where you can practice French with native speakers who want to practice your language in return. Tandem partners: Sign up for tandem language partnerships ‚Äî you meet regularly with a partner and split the time between practising each other's languages. Integration workshops: CAGI runs workshops on Swiss and French culture, local customs, and practical life topics ‚Äî all helpful for language and cultural integration. Local Options Alliance Francaise de Geneve: Well-established French language school offering group and private courses at all levels. Recognised certificates available. Universite Populaire du Canton de Geneve: Offers affordable French courses for all levels, as well as other languages and cultural classes. Commune integration courses (France): If you live in France (Pays de Gex area), your local commune or communaute de communes may offer free or low-cost French integration courses. Migros Club School: Switzerland's largest adult education provider offers French and other language courses at competitive prices across Geneva canton. Online platforms: Platforms like italki and Preply connect you with professional French tutors for private online lessons at flexible times and prices. Self-Study & Apps Duolingo: Free app with gamified French lessons. Good for building vocabulary and basic grammar, especially for absolute beginners. Babbel: Subscription-based app with structured French courses designed by linguists. More in-depth grammar explanations than Duolingo. TV5Monde: Free French-language media platform with news, shows, and dedicated language-learning exercises for all CEFR levels. RFI ‚Äî Journal en francais facile: Daily news broadcast in simplified French. Excellent for intermediate learners to improve listening comprehension. Immersion: Listen to French radio (France Inter, RTS La Premiere), watch French TV (TF1, France 2), and switch your phone and apps to French for passive daily exposure. Tips for Learning Start before arriving: If possible, begin learning basic French before you move to Geneva. Even a few weeks of self-study will make your first days much easier. Register early: CERN courses fill up within hours of opening. Set a reminder for the enrollment date and register immediately when it opens. Practice with locals: Use every opportunity to speak French ‚Äî at the market, in shops, at the boulangerie. Locals appreciate the effort even if your French is not perfect. Join social activities: Attend French-speaking social events, conversation groups, or join a local sports club where French is the common language. Sources CERN Learning Hub CERN Welcome Club CAGI ‚Äî Centre d'Accueil de la Geneve Internationale Alliance Francaise de Geneve 🖨 Print this guide

title: Clubs & Social Life at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Clubs & Social Life at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Clubs & Social Life Clubs & Social Life at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important Some popular sports clubs and courses have limited spots and fill up quickly at the start of each season. Register early and check the Staff Association website regularly for openings. Staff Association The CERN Staff Association is the elected body representing all CERN personnel. It advocates for employees' rights, working conditions, and benefits. Beyond representation, the Staff Association organises and manages a wide range of clubs, activities, and social events throughout the year. Membership in the Staff Association gives you access to subsidised club memberships, group insurance rates, discounts at local businesses, and various perks. The Staff Association offices are located in Building 504 on the Meyrin site. Visit their website or drop by for information on all available activities. Welcome Club For newcomers: The Welcome Club is specifically designed for newcomers to CERN and their families. It is one of the best ways to start building your social network. Social events: Regular coffee mornings, cultural outings, day trips to Swiss and French destinations, and seasonal celebrations bring members together. Language courses: The Welcome Club offers affordable French classes and conversation groups, particularly useful for partners who may not work at CERN. Playgroups: For families with young children, the Welcome Club organises playgroups where children and parents can socialise together. How to join: Visit the Welcome Club website or attend one of their regular welcome events. Membership is open to all CERN personnel and their families. Sports Clubs Over 70 clubs: CERN has more than 70 sports clubs and courses covering a huge range of activities ‚Äî from football, running, and swimming to skiing, tennis, yoga, martial arts, and cycling. Subsidised gym: The CERN fitness centre offers subsidised access for all personnel. Equipped with modern machines, free weights, and group class studios. Competitive teams: Several clubs field competitive teams that participate in local and regional leagues ‚Äî football, basketball, volleyball, and more. Registration: Browse the full list of sports clubs on the Staff Association website. Most clubs have an annual membership fee (typically modest) and welcome all skill levels. Cultural Clubs Music: The CERN music club, choir, and various bands bring together musicians of all levels. Concerts and jam sessions are held throughout the year. Photography & art: Photography and art clubs organise exhibitions, workshops, and outings. A great way to explore the region creatively. Wine & cooking: Wine-tasting clubs and cooking groups let you explore Swiss, French, and international cuisine with fellow enthusiasts. Film, theatre & dance: Film clubs, theatre groups, and dance classes (salsa, tango, swing, and more) provide cultural entertainment and creative outlets. Board games & more: Board game nights, book clubs, and other hobby groups meet regularly. Check the Staff Association directory for the full list. National Communities Country-specific groups: Many nationalities have their own informal communities at CERN ‚Äî Spanish, Italian, Greek, German, Portuguese, Indian, and many others. Cultural events: National groups organise celebrations for national holidays, traditional food events, and cultural presentations throughout the year. Mutual support: These communities provide practical advice for compatriots ‚Äî from finding a flat to navigating local bureaucracy in your native language. Finding your community: Ask colleagues from your country, check the CERN e-groups mailing lists, or look for your national community on social media and messaging platforms. Outdoor Activities Hiking: The Jura mountains and the Alps are at your doorstep. Hundreds of marked trails range from easy lakeside walks to challenging alpine routes. Skiing: The closest ski areas include Col de la Faucille and Crozet in the Jura (30 min drive), with major Alpine resorts like Chamonix, Verbier, and Flaine within 1-2 hours. Lake Geneva: Swimming, sailing, paddle boarding, and lakeside relaxation. Public beaches (plages) are free and well-maintained around the lake. Cycling: Excellent cycling infrastructure in both Switzerland and France. The CERN cycling club organises regular group rides and can recommend routes for all levels. Staff Association excursions: The Staff Association organises group excursions ‚Äî ski weekends, hiking trips, and cultural outings at subsidised prices. Social Events Hardronic Festival: CERN's annual music festival organised by the Staff Association, featuring live bands, food stalls, and a lively atmosphere on the CERN site. Summer BBQs: Departmental and group barbecues are a CERN tradition during the summer months. A relaxed way to socialise with colleagues outside the office. Christmas market: The annual CERN Christmas market brings seasonal treats, handmade crafts, and festive cheer to the Meyrin site each December. Public events: CERN regularly hosts public lectures, open days, and science exhibitions. These are excellent opportunities to invite family and friends to discover CERN. Science cafes: Informal science talks held at local cafes and venues around Geneva, organised by CERN outreach. Open to everyone and a great way to meet people beyond the CERN bubble. Tips Check the Staff Association website: The most up-to-date list of all clubs, activities, and events is maintained on the Staff Association website. Bookmark it and check regularly. Attend newcomer events: Welcome sessions and newcomer events are organised regularly. These are the easiest way to meet people and learn about available activities. Join early: Popular sports clubs and courses fill up fast, especially at the start of the academic year (September). Register as soon as enrollment opens. Build your network: Joining clubs and attending social events is one of the best ways to build a strong personal and professional network at CERN. Do not hesitate to try something new. title: Family Support at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Family Support at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Family Support Family Support at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important Relocating with your family requires early planning. Many CERN support programmes have application windows and eligibility conditions ‚Äî start the process as soon as you receive your contract. Relocating with Family CERN provides relocation support for employees arriving with their families. Contact the CERN Housing Service and HR department early to understand available assistance. A settling-in allowance may be available depending on your contract type. This one-time payment helps cover initial expenses such as deposits, temporary accommodation, and moving costs. The CERN Housing Service can assist with your housing search, providing listings and advice for both the Swiss and French sides of the border. Family checklist: Gather all necessary documents (passports, marriage certificates, birth certificates, translated and apostilled), arrange school enrolment, and plan health insurance coverage for all family members before arrival. Spouses & Partners Forum The CERN Spouses & Partners Forum is a CERN-supported network for the partners and spouses of CERN personnel. It helps newcomers integrate into life in the Geneva area. The forum organises regular meetings, social events, language courses, and cultural activities throughout the year. Career advice sessions and workshops are available to help partners explore employment and professional development opportunities in Switzerland and France. To connect with the forum, visit the CERN Welcome Club website or contact the CERN Staff Association for meeting schedules and registration details. Dual Career Support CERN runs a Dual Career programme specifically designed to support the professional lives of partners who relocate to the Geneva area. The programme offers career workshops, CV review sessions, and interview preparation tailored to the local Swiss and French job markets. Networking events connect partners with local employers, international organisations, and other professionals in the region. Job search resources include access to local job boards, guidance on Swiss and French employment practices, and information about work permits for non-EU nationals. Partner Employment Work rights for partners depend on the country of residence and the type of permit held. The rules differ significantly between Switzerland and France. Swiss carte de legitimation: Partners holding a dependent carte de legitimation may face restrictions on taking up paid employment in Switzerland. Check with the Swiss Mission or HR for your specific situation. French titre de sejour: If you reside in France, partners may benefit from more flexible work authorisation rules. A titre de sejour obtained through the French authorities can allow employment in France. International organisations: Partners can also explore employment at other international organisations in Geneva (UN, WHO, ILO, WTO, etc.), which may have their own hiring processes for family members of international civil servants. Family Allowances CERN provides family allowances including a child allowance for each dependent child. The amount varies based on the child's age and educational status. Education grants are available for children attending school or university, helping to cover tuition fees and related educational expenses. How to apply: Submit your application through the CERN HR portal. You will need birth certificates, proof of dependency, and educational enrolment documents. Apply promptly after joining CERN ‚Äî allowances are generally not paid retroactively for extended periods. Keep HR updated if your family situation changes (new child, change in schooling, etc.). Childcare & Parenting CERN does not operate its own creche, but the CERN Staff Association and Welcome Club maintain up-to-date lists of childcare options near CERN on both the Swiss and French sides. Parenting networks and baby/toddler groups operate through the CERN Welcome Club. These groups meet regularly and provide a support network for new parents in the area. Family-friendly events are organised throughout the year, including holiday activities, outings, and workshops for children of various ages. For detailed information on schools and childcare facilities, see the dedicated childcare and schools page on this site. Tips Join the Spouses Forum early: Connect with other families before or immediately after arrival. The forum is one of the best resources for settling in. Check partner work permit eligibility: Understand the work restrictions associated with your permit type before your partner starts a job search. Apply for family allowances promptly: Do not delay ‚Äî submit your allowance applications as soon as you have the required documents. Connect with the Welcome Club families section: The Welcome Club organises activities specifically for families with children and is an excellent way to build a social network. title: Medical Services & Emergencies at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Medical Services & Emergencies at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Daily Life / Medical Services & Emergencies Medical Services & Emergencies at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important In a life-threatening emergency at CERN, dial 74444 (internal) or +41 22 767 4444 (external). Outside CERN, dial 144 (Switzerland) or 15 (France) for an ambulance, or 112 for the European emergency number. CERN Medical Service The CERN Medical Service is located in Building 57 on the Meyrin site. It provides occupational health services, general medical consultations, vaccinations, and medical certificates. Opening hours: Monday to Friday, 8:00-12:00 and 13:30-17:00. The Medical Service is closed on weekends and CERN closure days. Appointments can be booked by phone or through the CERN Medical Service website. Walk-ins may be accepted depending on availability. No out-of-hours emergency service: The CERN Medical Service does not provide emergency care outside of opening hours. For emergencies outside working hours, call the CERN Fire Brigade (74444) or go to a hospital. CERN Infirmary The CERN Infirmary provides first aid and treatment for minor injuries and ailments on the CERN site during working hours. The infirmary can handle minor cuts, bruises, headaches, and similar non-urgent conditions. It is not equipped for serious injuries or emergencies. If you have a minor health issue during the workday, visit the infirmary first. For anything more serious, contact the CERN Fire Brigade (74444) or go to a hospital directly. Emergency at CERN CERN emergency number: Dial 74444 from any internal CERN phone, or +41 22 767 4444 from a mobile phone. This connects you to the CERN Fire Brigade, which coordinates all emergency responses on site. The CERN Fire Brigade is trained to respond to medical emergencies, fires, chemical spills, and other incidents. They are available 24/7. Defibrillators: Automated external defibrillators (AEDs) are available at various locations across the CERN site. Look for the green AED signs in buildings. What to do in an emergency: Call 74444, state your location clearly (building and room number), describe the situation, do not hang up until told to do so, and send someone to meet the emergency team at the building entrance if possible. Hospitals HUG (Hopitaux Universitaires de Geneve): The main hospital in Geneva with a 24/7 emergency department (urgences). Located at Rue Gabrielle-Perret-Gentil 4, 1205 Geneva. Accessible by tram 15 or bus. Centre Hospitalier du Pays de Gex: A smaller hospital located in Gex, France, closer to CERN for those living on the French side. It has an emergency department for less critical cases. Meyrin medical centres: Several medical centres and clinics in Meyrin and surrounding areas offer walk-in appointments and minor urgent care during business hours. Finding a Doctor To find a general practitioner (medecin generaliste), you can register with a local doctor near your residence. In Switzerland, you do not always need a referral to see a specialist, but some insurance plans require one. Swiss system: Use online directories or ask your commune for a list of local doctors accepting new patients. Waiting lists can be long in the Geneva area. French system: Register with a medecin traitant (primary care doctor) through the French healthcare system. This is recommended to receive full reimbursement rates. The CERN Medical Service can recommend doctors and specialists in the area. Ask at your next appointment or contact them by phone. Pharmacies Swiss pharmacies: Several pharmacies are located in Meyrin and Vernier, close to CERN. They are open during standard business hours and can dispense prescriptions from Swiss or CERN doctors. French pharmacies: Pharmacies in Saint-Genis-Pouilly and Ferney-Voltaire serve the French side of the border. They accept French prescriptions and some Swiss prescriptions. Sunday/night pharmacies (pharmacie de garde): A rotating schedule determines which pharmacy is open on Sundays, holidays, and at night. Check the local pharmacie de garde schedule online or on the pharmacy door. Prescriptions from CERN Medical Service are generally accepted at both Swiss and French pharmacies. Keep your CHIS card with you for reimbursement purposes. Mental Health CERN provides psychological support through the CERN Medical Service. You can request an appointment with a psychologist through the standard booking process. Employee Assistance Programme (EAP): CERN offers a confidential Employee Assistance Programme that provides short-term counselling, crisis support, and referral services. This service is available to all CERN personnel and their family members. External resources include private psychologists and psychiatrists in the Geneva area. The CERN Medical Service can provide referrals. Confidentiality: All mental health consultations, whether through the CERN Medical Service or the EAP, are strictly confidential and are not shared with your supervisor or HR department. Emergency Numbers Service Number CERN Fire Brigade 74444 / +41 22 767 4444 Swiss Ambulance 144 Swiss Police 117 Swiss Fire Service 118 French SAMU (Emergency Medical) 15 French Police 17 French Fire Service 18 European Emergency 112 Sources CERN Medical Service HUG ‚Äî Hopitaux Universitaires de Geneve Swiss Emergency Services (144) French SAMU Emergency Services 🖨 Print this guide

title: Permits & Registration at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Permits & Registration at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Legal & Tax Help / Permits & Registration Permits & Registration at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Disclaimer This page is for general informational purposes only. It does not constitute legal advice. Always consult with the CERN Users Office or a qualified advisor for your specific situation. Overview As staff of an international organisation, CERN employees have a special permit status. You do not need a standard Swiss or French work permit to work at CERN. Your legal status is managed through CERN and the host state agreements with Switzerland and France. The CERN Users Office is your main point of contact for all permit and registration matters. Swiss Carte de Legitimation What it is: The Carte de Legitimation is an identity document issued by the DFAE (Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs) that certifies your status as a member of an international organisation. Types: The type depends on your nationality and contract. Common types include B and C (with full customs privileges), D and E (limited customs privileges), P (scientific personnel), and S (Swiss nationals). Types H, F, and G have no special customs privileges. How to obtain: Obtained through the CERN Users Office, which processes the application with the DFAE on your behalf. You must register within 14 days of your arrival. Validity: The carte de legitimation validity is linked to the duration of your CERN contract. It must be renewed if your contract is extended. Benefits: The carte de legitimation exempts you from standard Swiss work and residence permits, and provides certain tax and customs advantages. French Titre de Sejour Who needs it: If you live in France (e.g. in the Pays de Gex), you need a titre de sejour (residence permit) in addition to your CERN carte de legitimation. Special category: International organisation employees have a special titre de sejour category, different from standard work permits. Where to apply: Apply at the prefecture of Ain (Bourg-en-Bresse) or the sub-prefecture corresponding to your place of residence. Documents needed: Passport, proof of address, CERN contract, carte de legitimation, passport photos, completed application form. Renewal: The titre de sejour must be renewed before its expiry date. Start the renewal process well in advance (at least 2 months before). The 14-Day Rule Obligation: You must register with the CERN Users Office within 14 days of your arrival. This is a strict requirement. What it triggers: Registration triggers the carte de legitimation application process and establishes your legal status in Switzerland. Late registration consequences: Late registration can delay your carte de legitimation, affect your health insurance coverage, and cause administrative complications. Family Members Dependent cards: Your spouse/partner and children receive their own legitimation cards as dependents of the primary holder. Spouse/partner registration: Your spouse or registered partner must be declared to the Users Office. Common-law partners may have different requirements depending on nationality. Children: Minor children are included in your registration. Adult children may require additional paperwork. Documents needed: Marriage certificate, children's birth certificates, sworn translations into English or French if documents are in another language, Hague apostille if applicable. Changing Residence Switzerland to France: If you move from Switzerland to France, you must notify the CERN Users Office, apply for a French titre de sejour, and update your address. France to Switzerland: If you move from France to Switzerland, you must register with the relevant Swiss commune and notify the Users Office. New permits needed: A change of country of residence requires new permits. The process can take several weeks, so plan ahead. Timeline: Notify the Users Office as soon as possible, ideally before the move. Deadline requirements vary by country. Practical Tips Start your paperwork immediately upon arrival. Do not wait. Keep copies of all documents (physical and digital). You will need copies on multiple occasions. The CERN Users Office is your main point of contact for any permit and registration questions. Have passport photos ready (Swiss format: 35x45 mm) for cards and permits. If you have family members, gather all necessary documents (certificates, translations) before arriving. title: CERN Taxation System - CERN Starter Pack
content: CERN Taxation System - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Legal & Tax Help / CERN Taxation CERN Taxation System Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Disclaimer This page is for general informational purposes only. It does not constitute tax or legal advice. Always consult a qualified tax advisor for your specific situation. CERN Internal Tax CERN levies its own internal tax on salaries. This tax is deducted directly from your pay slip and is not a national tax. The rates are progressive, similar in structure to a national income tax, but administered internally by CERN. The internal tax has been in force since 1 January 2005, pursuant to the Protocol on Privileges and Immunities signed by Member States in 2004 and the CERN Council decision of 15 September 2005. The internal tax is mandatory for all CERN staff and is calculated automatically each month. National Income Tax Exemption CERN salaries are exempt from national income tax under the Protocol on Privileges and Immunities of international organisations. This exemption applies in the host states (Switzerland and France) and in most CERN member states. The exemption applies only to CERN salary. Other income (investments, rental, freelance work) remains subject to normal taxation. French Citizens Exception French nationals working at CERN and living in France may be subject to French income tax on their CERN salary. Special provisions apply and the situation can be complex. If you are a French citizen, you must consult a tax advisor. This exception applies regardless of the type of contract you hold at CERN. Swiss Residents No Swiss income tax applies to CERN salary. However, wealth tax (impot sur la fortune) still applies at cantonal and communal level. Non-CERN income (rental, investments, self-employment) is subject to Swiss cantonal and communal taxes. You must file an annual Swiss tax return, declaring your wealth and any non-CERN income. French Residents For non-French nationals, no French income tax applies to CERN salary. However, you must still file an annual French tax return. You must declare your worldwide income, including your CERN salary, but the CERN salary is declared as exempt income. Non-CERN income (rental, investments) is subject to French income tax at standard rates. The taux effectif may apply: the exempt CERN salary can be taken into account when calculating the tax rate applicable to your other income. Outside Income Income from investments, rental property, freelance work, or other sources IS taxable in your country of residence. You must report all non-CERN income in your annual tax return in your country of residence. Double taxation treaties between countries may affect how this income is taxed. Consult a tax advisor. Spain-Specific Considerations CERN employees who maintain their tax residence in Spain have specific obligations. The CERN salary is exempt from IRPF, but it must be declared. Additionally, Modelo 720 obligations for declaring foreign assets apply when the established thresholds are exceeded. See our detailed guide on the Spanish Tax Declaration See our guide on Modelo 720 Practical Tips Keep all CERN pay slips. You will need them for your tax returns. Always declare your CERN salary in your tax return, even if it is exempt. Not declaring it can cause problems. Consult a qualified tax advisor if you have complex situations (dual residence, multiple income sources, etc.). Tax treaties between countries matter. Your situation may vary depending on your nationality and country of residence. title: CERN Pension Fund - CERN Starter Pack
content: CERN Pension Fund - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Legal & Tax Help / Pension Fund CERN Pension Fund Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Disclaimer This page is for general informational purposes only. It does not constitute financial advice. Always consult a qualified financial advisor and CERN HR for your specific situation. Overview The CERN Pension Fund (CERN PF) is a defined-benefit scheme. This means your pension is calculated based on your years of service and salary, not just the contributions made. Membership in the CERN PF is mandatory for all CERN staff and fellows. The CERN PF is one of the largest international organisation pension funds, with professionally managed investments. Contributions Employee contribution: Approximately 10.1% of your monthly salary is automatically deducted as your pension fund contribution. CERN contribution: CERN contributes approximately 20.2% of your salary, i.e. double your personal contribution. Total: The total contribution is approximately 30.3% of your monthly salary, shared between you and CERN. Automatic deduction: Contributions are deducted monthly from your pay slip. No action is required on your part. Benefits by Years of Service Less than 5 years: If you leave CERN with fewer than 5 years of service, you receive a lump-sum transfer value. You are not entitled to a pension. 5 to 10 years: You can choose between a deferred pension (paid upon reaching retirement age) or a transfer value to another pension scheme. 10+ years: You are entitled to a pension upon reaching retirement age. The amount depends on your years of service and average salary. 15+ years: Full pension eligibility. Access to all retirement options, including early retirement with a smaller reduction. Retirement Ages Normal retirement: Age 65 if you joined the Pension Fund on or before 31 December 2011, or age 67 if you joined on or after 1 January 2012. Early retirement: Possible from age 50 (pre-2012 members) or age 52 (post-2012 members) with at least 5 years of service, but with an actuarial reduction for each year of advancement. Late retirement: It is possible to delay retirement beyond age 65 in certain circumstances, with an increase in the pension. Flexible transition: Options exist for a gradual transition to retirement, including part-time work before full retirement. Transfer Value What it is: The transfer value is a sum calculated based on your accumulated contributions plus interest. It is offered to those leaving CERN before pension eligibility. Transfer to another scheme: The value can be transferred to your new employer's pension scheme or to the national pension system of your country. Process and timing: You must elect what to do with your transfer value within 3 months of leaving CERN. Payment or transfer is processed once your request is submitted. Pension Calculation Calculation basis: The pension is calculated based on your years of service and your average salary over the last years. Accrual rate: 2% per year of service (pre-2012 members, max 35 years) or 1.85% per year (post-2012 members, max 37 years and 10 months). Maximum pension: The pension may not exceed your final basic salary. The maximum accrual is 70% for pre-2012 members (35 √ó 2%) or approximately 70% for post-2012 members. Survivor's pension: In case of death, your spouse and dependents may receive a survivor's pension. Disability pension: If you become permanently incapacitated, you may be entitled to a disability pension. Leaving CERN Options: The options available depend on your years of service. Review all alternatives carefully before deciding. Election deadline: You must communicate your choice within 3 months of departure. No retroactive changes are possible. Financial advice: It is highly recommended to obtain professional financial advice before making any pension decision. Tax implications: The tax implications of receiving a lump sum vs. a periodic pension can be very different depending on your country of residence. Practical Tips Check your pension estimate on the CERN HR portal regularly to plan your future. Consider years of service when planning career moves. The differences between 4 and 5 years, or between 9 and 10 years, are significant. Get professional financial advice before leaving CERN, especially if you have more than 5 years of service. Understand the implications of transfer value versus deferred pension before making a decision. title: Contracts & Career at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Contracts & Career at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Legal & Tax Help / Contracts & Career Contracts & Career at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Disclaimer This page is for general informational purposes only. Always consult CERN HR or the Staff Association for up-to-date information on your contractual situation. Contract Types Staff: Indefinite or limited duration contract. The most stable contract type at CERN, with full access to all benefits. Fellow: Limited duration contract, maximum 3 years. Aimed at post-doctoral or early-career professionals. Doctoral Student: Programme of maximum 3 years for doctoral students registered at a home university. Associate: Staff sent by member state institutes to work on specific CERN projects. User: Affiliated researcher who uses CERN facilities but is not a direct employee. Staff Contracts Limited duration (LD): Staff contracts typically start as limited duration (LD), which can be extended up to a maximum of 8 years in total. During this period you may apply for an indefinite contract. Indefinite duration: After the LD contract review, an indefinite duration contract may be granted. This depends on performance and CERN's needs. Grades and steps: CERN staff are classified into grades (reflecting level of responsibility) and steps (reflecting experience). Step advancement is annual. Career paths: Technical, administrative, and research career paths exist, each with its own progression criteria. Fellowship Programme Profile: Aimed at post-doctoral or early-career professionals in physics, engineering, computing, or other relevant disciplines. Duration: Maximum 3 years. Fellowship contracts cannot be extended beyond this limit. Competitive selection: The selection process is highly competitive, with periodic calls and evaluation committees. One-time opportunity: The fellowship programme is a one-time opportunity. You cannot re-apply for the same programme after completing it. Remuneration: Fellows receive a monthly stipend plus installation, travel, and, where applicable, family allowances. Doctoral Students Programme: The CERN Doctoral Student programme allows doctoral research to be carried out at CERN facilities. Duration: Maximum 3 years. Students must be enrolled at a home university throughout the entire period. Stipend: Doctoral students receive a monthly stipend and allowances. Conditions differ from those of fellows. Extension Rules Staff LD: Limited duration staff contracts are reviewed at 5 years. Extension or conversion to indefinite depends on performance and needs. Fellows: Fellowship contracts cannot be extended beyond 3 years in total. There are no exceptions to this rule. Maximum cumulative employment: Rules exist on the maximum cumulative duration of employment at CERN under different contract types. Gaps between contracts: Mandatory gaps may be required between certain consecutive contract types. Career Development Annual reviews (MARS): All staff participate in the annual MARS (Merit Appraisal and Recognition of Staff) review system, which evaluates performance and sets objectives. Training: CERN offers extensive technical, language, and professional development training opportunities through the Learning Hub. Internal mobility: Mobility between departments and projects is encouraged to broaden experience and skills. Promotion: Promotion criteria include performance, competencies, experience, and availability of positions at higher grades. Career counselling: CERN offers career counselling services to help staff plan their career path. Leaving CERN Notice periods: Notice periods vary by contract type and seniority. Check your contract or with HR for exact timelines. End-of-contract procedures: Include returning equipment, closing accounts, pension procedures, and updating permits. Indemnities: Depending on contract type and length of service, you may be entitled to end-of-contract indemnities. Pension options: Your pension options depend on your years of service. See the Pension Fund page for details. Repatriation grant: Expatriate staff may be entitled to a repatriation grant at the end of their contract. Certificate of employment: CERN issues a certificate of employment at the end of your contract, detailing your position and period of service. Practical Tips Understand your contract type and its duration limits from day one. Plan ahead for the end of your contract, especially if you are a fellow or doctoral student. Use CERN's career counselling services to plan your career path. Keep track of your MARS reviews and professional achievements. Sources & Documentation CERN Staff Rules and Regulations CERN HR - Contracts Service CERN Staff Association CERN Admin e-Guide 🖨 Print this guide

title: Safety Training at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Safety Training at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Technical Help / Safety Training Safety Training at CERN Last updated: February 2026 All newcomers must complete mandatory safety training before being granted access to CERN sites. Plan to start the online modules as early as possible. Mandatory Safety Course Every person working at CERN must complete a general safety awareness course before accessing the sites. This course covers the essential topics you need to know to stay safe on CERN premises. Fire safety and evacuation procedures Electrical hazard awareness Radiation awareness fundamentals Emergency contacts and reporting The course has both an online component (e-learning) and an on-site component. You can begin the online portion before arriving at CERN, which is strongly recommended to speed up the registration process. Types of Safety Training Depending on your role and the areas you will work in, you may need one or more of the following training courses: General Safety (Level 1) — Mandatory for all personnel. Covers basic site safety, fire prevention, and evacuation. Radiation Protection (Level 2/3) — Required for work in accelerator tunnels or experimental areas. Level depends on exposure category. Electrical Safety — Required for anyone working on or near electrical installations. Cryogenics Safety — Needed if you work near cryogenic systems, especially around the LHC. Chemical Safety — For personnel handling chemical substances in laboratories. Working at Heights — Required for tasks involving ladders, scaffolding, or elevated platforms. E-Learning Platform CERN provides safety e-learning modules through the Learning Hub platform. These modules can be completed before your arrival, allowing you to begin work more quickly once on site. Access the Safety e-learning section on the CERN Learning Hub Mandatory modules are flagged clearly in your training profile Certificates are stored automatically in your profile upon completion You can track your progress and see upcoming deadlines On-Site Training Some safety courses include practical on-site sessions that cannot be replaced by e-learning. These sessions provide hands-on experience with safety equipment and procedures. Fire extinguisher handling practice Evacuation drills for your building Building-specific safety briefings from your safety officer Schedule practical sessions through your supervisor or the HSE unit Certification Renewal Safety certifications are not permanent. Most need to be renewed periodically to ensure your knowledge stays up to date. Most general certifications are valid for 3 to 5 years Radiation protection training typically requires renewal every 3 years The system sends you an automatic notification before your certification expires Re-certification usually involves retaking the e-learning module and, in some cases, the on-site session Specific Hazards at CERN CERN is a unique environment with hazards not found in typical workplaces. Be aware of the following: Radiation zones — CERN has supervised and controlled radiation areas. Access requires specific training and dosimetry equipment. Cryogenic risks — The LHC operates at extremely low temperatures. Cryogenic leaks can displace oxygen and cause cold burns. Electrical installations — High-voltage equipment is present in many areas. Only qualified personnel may work on these systems. Confined spaces — Some areas have restricted ventilation. Entry requires a permit and specific training. Overhead cranes — Heavy lifting equipment is used in experimental halls. Stay clear of marked zones during operations. Safety Rules on Site Wear your CERN badge visibly at all times while on site Follow all zone access restrictions — never enter areas you are not authorized for Report any incident or unsafe situation immediately to your safety officer Never enter the accelerator tunnel without explicit authorization Know the contact details of your building safety officer and the CERN Fire Brigade (phone 74444) References CERN HSE (Health, Safety & Environment) CERN Safety E-Learning (Learning Hub) CERN Safety Rules Print this page

title: Access Cards at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Access Cards at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Technical Help / Access Cards Access Cards at CERN Last updated: February 2026 Your CERN access card is your primary identification on site. It must be worn visibly at all times and is required for entering buildings, gates, and restricted areas. CERN Access Card The CERN access card is issued during your registration at the Users Office. It serves as your ID badge and grants physical access to the CERN sites. The card is RFID-enabled and works with door readers and gate barriers across the campus. You must carry your access card at all times while on CERN premises. It is used not only for building access but also for identification purposes during security checks. Card Types Staff card (blue) — Issued to CERN staff members with employment contracts. User card (pink/red) — Issued to registered users, fellows, and associates. Contractor card — Issued to personnel from external companies working on CERN projects. Visitor card — Temporary card for short-term visitors, typically valid for a single day or event. The validity period of your card depends on your contract type. Staff cards are typically valid for the duration of the contract, while user cards may need periodic renewal. Getting Your Card Your access card is issued at the Users Office (Building 55) during your initial registration. You will need the following documents: Valid passport or national ID card Contract letter or appointment confirmation from CERN A passport-style photo (can be taken on site if needed) The process is typically completed on the same day. You will also undergo biometric registration (fingerprint) which is linked to your card for access to certain restricted areas. Building & Zone Access Not all buildings at CERN have the same access level. Your card grants you access to general areas by default, but specific buildings and zones may require additional authorization. Request additional building access through the ADaMS system (Access and Safety at CERN) Your supervisor must approve access requests for restricted zones Accelerator tunnels and experimental caverns require specific safety training before access is granted Access rights are reviewed periodically and may be revoked if training expires Vehicle Access If you drive to CERN, you need a separate vehicle sticker in addition to your personal access card. The gate barriers use your badge to verify authorization. Apply for a vehicle sticker through the ADaMS system Different parking zones exist — check which zone your building belongs to Present your badge at the vehicle gate for entry and exit Bicycle access does not require a sticker but you should still carry your badge ADaMS Mobile ADaMS (Access and Safety at CERN) also has a mobile application that lets you manage your access rights and safety information on the go. Check your current access rights and authorizations Request new building or zone access View your safety training status and upcoming renewals Access emergency contacts and safety information Download the app from the CERN internal app distribution system Lost or Stolen Card If your access card is lost or stolen, take the following steps immediately: Report the loss to the Users Office as soon as possible The lost card will be deactivated immediately to prevent unauthorized access A replacement card will be issued — bring your passport or ID for verification Temporary access arrangements can be made while waiting for the replacement Leaving CERN When your contract or association with CERN ends, you must complete the following steps regarding your access card: Return your access card to the Users Office on your last day Your badge and all associated access rights will be deactivated Complete the final clearance process, which includes returning equipment and settling administrative matters References CERN Users Office ADaMS (Access and Safety at CERN) CERN Access Policy Print this page

title: Telework Policy at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Telework Policy at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Technical Help / Telework Policy Telework Policy at CERN Last updated: February 2026 CERN's telework policy allows up to 40% remote work for eligible personnel. Always check the latest version of Operational Circular No. 7 (OC7) for the most current rules. Overview CERN's telework policy is governed by Operational Circular No. 7 (OC7). It establishes a hybrid working model that aims to balance on-site presence with flexibility for remote work. The policy recognizes that many tasks can be performed remotely while maintaining the collaborative environment that is essential for CERN's research mission. However, on-site presence remains important for teamwork, hands-on activities, and building professional relationships. Eligibility Telework is available to staff members and fellows with an active CERN contract Doctoral students should check with their supervisor regarding eligibility, as it may depend on the experiment or group Not all roles are eligible — positions requiring hands-on technical work, laboratory presence, or shift duties may not qualify New employees are generally recommended to work on-site initially to build relationships and learn procedures before starting telework The 40% Limit The maximum proportion of working time that can be spent teleworking is 40% , which typically translates to about 2 days per week for a full-time schedule. The 40% is calculated over a reference period, not on a strict weekly basis Your supervisor has discretion in how the schedule is organized Some weeks you may telework more and others less, as long as the average stays within the limit Part-time employees have the same 40% ratio applied to their contracted hours Approval Process To begin teleworking, you must submit a formal request through the official channels: Submit your telework request through EDH (Electronic Document Handling) Your direct supervisor must approve the request Your section leader or group leader provides endorsement Telework agreements are typically reviewed on an annual basis Location Requirements Where you telework from matters. There are important legal and administrative considerations regarding your telework location. You must telework from your country of residence (typically Switzerland or France) Working from a third country (outside CH/FR) requires special approval and is generally limited Extended work from another country may have tax implications — consult HR if in doubt Insurance coverage may be affected if you telework from an unapproved location Equipment & Connectivity CERN provides the essential tools for remote work, but you are responsible for ensuring a suitable home working environment. CERN provides a laptop suitable for remote work VPN access through the CERN VPN client for secure connection to internal resources Zoom and Microsoft Teams are available for video meetings and collaboration You are responsible for your home internet connection Discuss any additional equipment needs (monitor, keyboard, etc.) with your supervisor Schedule & Availability When teleworking, you are expected to maintain your regular availability and be reachable by your team. You must be reachable during core hours : 09:30–11:30 and 14:00–16:00 Keep your calendar visible and up to date so colleagues know your availability Flexible scheduling is possible within the agreed limits — coordinate with your team Be responsive on Mattermost, email, and other communication channels during working hours Practical Tips Discuss expectations and preferred telework days with your supervisor early in your contract Establish a consistent routine to maintain productivity and work-life balance Stay visible to your team — participate actively in meetings and team channels Prioritize on-site attendance for important events, workshops, and team meetings Keep your telework agreement up to date and renew it before it expires References CERN Operational Circular No. 7 (OC7) CERN HR Telework Page CERN Staff Association Print this page

title: Doctoral Students Guide at CERN - CERN Starter Pack
content: Doctoral Students Guide at CERN - CERN Starter Pack Skip to main content Home / Doctoral Guide Doctoral Students Guide at CERN Last updated: February 2026 ⚠️ Important CERN does not award PhD degrees. You must remain enrolled at your home university throughout your doctoral work. Make sure you understand your university's requirements before starting at CERN. CERN & Doctoral Students CERN does not award PhD degrees. Your doctorate is granted by your home university, and you must remain registered there throughout your time at CERN. CERN provides a world-class research environment, access to unique experimental facilities, and expert supervision for your doctoral research. You will typically have both a CERN supervisor (for day-to-day research guidance) and a university supervisor (for academic and thesis requirements). The typical duration for doctoral work at CERN is 3 to 4 years, depending on your university's programme and your research progress. Doctoral Student Programme The CERN Doctoral Student programme is the main channel for PhD students to work at CERN. It is open to students enrolled in a doctoral programme at a university in a CERN Member or Associate Member State. Eligibility: You must be enrolled in a PhD programme, have a university supervisor, and your research topic must align with CERN's scientific activities. There are typically two application rounds per year. Contract: Doctoral students receive a limited-duration contract (usually up to 3 years). The contract includes a monthly stipend, travel allowance, and health insurance (CHIS). Stipend: The monthly stipend covers living expenses in the Geneva area. The exact amount is reviewed periodically. A travel allowance for one return trip per year to your home institution is also provided. Thesis at CERN Your thesis is submitted to and evaluated by your home university, following their academic procedures and requirements. CERN does not grant the degree. CERN supervisor role: Your CERN supervisor provides day-to-day research guidance, helps you navigate the CERN environment, and typically serves on your thesis committee or as an external reviewer. Thesis committee: You may have a thesis committee with members from both CERN and your university. Regular progress reviews are common practice. CERN-THESIS registration: All theses based on work done at CERN must be registered in the CERN Document Server (CDS) under the CERN-THESIS collection. This ensures your work is archived and accessible. CERN requires open access publication of your thesis. Hyper-Authorship Large experimental collaborations at CERN (such as ATLAS, CMS, ALICE, and LHCb) publish papers with author lists of 3,000 or more physicists. This is known as hyper-authorship. If you are a member of one of these collaborations, you will appear as an author on all papers published by the collaboration during your membership period, regardless of your direct involvement in each analysis. Implications for your CV: Hyper-authored papers demonstrate collaboration membership but may not clearly show your individual contribution. Highlight your specific analysis contributions separately on your CV. Single-author thesis papers: Your thesis itself and any single-author or small-group papers you publish are important for demonstrating your individual research capability. Discuss publication strategy with your supervisors early. Practical Matters Contract duration: Doctoral student contracts are typically for up to 3 years. Extensions may be possible in exceptional cases but are not guaranteed. Social security: As a CERN doctoral student, you are covered by the CERN social security scheme. This includes pension contributions and insurance coverage during your contract. Health insurance: You are enrolled in CHIS (CERN Health Insurance Scheme). See the health insurance page on this site for details about coverage and the droit d'option if you live in France. Accommodation: CERN hostel rooms may be available for your initial weeks. After that, you will need to find private housing. The CERN Housing Service can help with your search. Travel budget: A travel allowance is provided for attending conferences, workshops, and visits to your home university. Discuss your travel plan with your supervisor and the relevant CERN department. Computing & Resources CERN computing account: You will receive a CERN computing account upon arrival. This gives you access to email, the CERN network, and all central computing services. lxplus: The lxplus interactive login service provides access to a shared Linux computing cluster for analysis work. Connect via SSH using your CERN credentials. EOS storage: EOS is CERN's large-scale storage system. You will have personal and project storage space for your data and analysis files. CERN GitLab: Use CERN's GitLab instance for version control and code collaboration. Most experiments and groups maintain their software repositories there. Indico & Mattermost: Indico is used for scheduling meetings, conferences, and events. Mattermost is CERN's internal messaging platform for team communication. After Your PhD CERN fellowships: After completing your PhD, you can apply for CERN Research or Applied fellowships. These are competitive positions lasting 1-3 years. Postdoc options: Many former CERN doctoral students continue in postdoctoral positions at CERN, at other laboratories, or at universities worldwide. Leaving CERN: When your contract ends, you must complete the CERN departure procedure, which includes returning equipment, settling accounts, and obtaining clearance from various services. Alumni network: CERN has an active alumni network. Stay connected for career opportunities, events, and to maintain your professional network in high-energy physics and beyond. Tips Maintain close contact with your home university: Regular communication with your university supervisor and department is essential. Do not let the physical distance create an academic gap. Attend CERN Academic Training: CERN offers an extensive academic training programme with lectures and courses. These are excellent for broadening your knowledge and meeting researchers from other fields. Network at workshops and conferences: Take advantage of CERN's central position in the physics community. Attend workshops, present your work, and build your professional network early. Plan your thesis writing timeline early: Do not leave thesis writing to the last months. Start structuring your thesis and writing chapters well in advance of your expected submission date.
